reviewText: It has been quite some time since I have had the pleasure to see such a fantastic Sci Fi - Thriller. The story is smart and engaging, the film is incredibly detailed and stylistically mindblowing. It has been incredibly photographed and superbly edited. The actors are great as well. The soundtrack is pulse-pounding and atmospheric. So, I guess most of the professional reviewers who give this movie bad grades obviously have quite strange ideas what makes a film great and what doesn't, as far as I'm concerned I couldn't be happier with how Oblivion turned out. Great imagery is not contrary to good storytelling, in fact good movies tell aspects of the story through their visuals as is the case with Oblivion. I believe Joseph Kosinski is definitely the most interesting and talented director starting his career in the last few years for sure. I give this film my highest recommendation, and I am really diappointed that even a piece of work and art such as this mostly gets bashed by people who would probably never come up with anything like it themselves...

the graphics are great, set up for a what I figured to be a fantastic sci fi thriller, however the plot is poorly written and slow.  The trailer shows it too be nothing like it really is, kind of like one of those movies where they show you all the best parts of a movie in a 3 minute trailer.

I would say cruise does a descent job with it but as i said poorly written and maybe poorly directed even?
they set you up to think the ending will really shock you or something but it's not even close to what I think they were expecting.

There is really not enough contact with the humans on the planet and more trying to impress people with CGI graphics.

The ending was not super bad but also very predictable.

I won't be buying this one that's for sure....

Being one of my highly anticipated movies of 2013, I was fortunate enough to get to see this movie early. And it very much  exceeded my expectations. Tom Cruise while, he is a good actor, really disappointed me with the 2012 movie Jack Reacher. But in this particular review, I am here to tell you that Oblivion is a re vamp for Tom Cruise.  This is a great science fiction movie. I will not spoil anything. Supporting cast includes Morgan Freeman, Olga Kurylenko (She is beautiful) and Andrea Riseborough; and they all did a outstanding job. I was mainly impressed how fast paced Oblivion was, and how i was still able to enjoy the movie. The visuals/effects were very well done in the movie as well. The storyline is predictable at some points but its nothing MAJOR to worry about. Other than the somewhat predictable parts of the storyline, I can find really nothing else to complain about. Oblivion is one of the best Sci Fi films of 2013. More importantly, it is a movie that i think anyone can enjoy.

4.5 stars

In the year 2077 Jack (Tom Cruise) and Victoria (Andrea Riseborough) are a working couple who live in a tower on the planet earth. We are given the background: Aliens called Scavengers or "Scavs" destroyed the moon. The earth went into turmoil. We managed to defeat them through the use of nuclear weapons. With our planet uninhabitable, our people went to live on Titan. An orbiting triangle space station gives orders to Jack whose mission is to maintain an army of drones used to hunt the remnants of the scavengers.

Jack's memory was erased in case aliens capture him. He has dreams of a woman (Olga Kurylenko)in NYC from a time long before the invasion. About the time Morgan Freeman shows up, things tie together, we get the twist, and the film takes off in a different direction.

The characters in the film are dry. The dialouge was boring. The action moved slow with the film definitely being too long. I enjoyed the one early scene where Cruise attempts a "Mission Impossible" type of escape, one that fails. The cinematography was great with a decent story line. If you love science fiction and are tired of those SyFy films, this is a welcomed change with neat killer drones and landscapes.

I am sure Cruise didn't have to beat himself up too much to accept the role of Luke Skywalker, Captain Steven Hiller (Will Smith, Independence), and Harry Stamper (Bruce Willis, Armageddon) all wrapped into one as he saves the world from alien invaders. This film is an obvious Scientology film just like "Battlefield Earth". Tom Cruise believes, according to "Going Clear: Scientology, Hollywood & the Prison of Belief" that he will actually save the planet from alien invaders. Gotta love it.

Parental Guide: One f-bombs (1 SOB) no sex, no real nudity. Brief sensuality. Brief Riseborough buttocks (?).

With varying degree, I enjoy most Tom cruise films. I know I'm in for a charismatic performance and a large production budget so I usually tag in to see how good Hollywood can be.

This film has some solid sci-fi ingredients: set in the future, man vs. aliens, human cloning (mild spoiler alert), dystopian earth, robots, etc. and it's all very slick but very quiet as earth is shown as a functioning earth. The setting and look of the film are cool enough to carry most viewers through act one with ease. Act II leads to the unveiling of act III that's loaded with enough Twilight Zoneish irony to create a mild eye roll.

Hollywood loves irony. Whereas I like it. But I really like villains as I believe they can make or break a story. Jaws, Alien, Star Wars - the villain drives the bus (even the film's title) and gives the story impact. Note: only one of those three films contains any irony.  You never really get a sense of a villain in this story until act III when all of the irony cards are played so viewers get to have that a-ha moment - ala most episodes of The Twilight Zone.

I am constantly saying to others that I don't like Tom Cruise "the person", but they could give this guy an empty box and a stick and he could make it an interesting movie.  Oblivion is not the favorite type of movie for me, but with that being said, this movie allows us to take a peek behind the curtain of reality and the future, or at least the future how a certain segment of our population believes (basically the movie industry).

Once we get past the underlying political statement being made about what happens when everything goes wrong, this is actually a well done movie with a pretty awesome ending.  Cruise, as he does whether it's in Mission Impossible, Top Gun, Edge of Tomorrow or Jack Reacher, takes what in many ways would be an average movie and moves it up several notches.  I was wavering somewhere between 4 and 5 stars and what pushed my rating to 5 stars was the 4K Ultra HD HDR rendition of this release which was just a prime example of why people should upgrade their systems to 4K.....one word....."awesome!"

Always I remind myself that Tom Cruise may have gone totally wonko, but that doesn't mean his movies aren't still good. And pretty much anything with Morgan Freeman has to be restaurant quality. I kept hoping that we'd get to see some part of the human civilization to be set up on Titan, but the story is confined to Earth and immediate vicinity. Good times.

Ok, the action sequences took way too much of this movie.  They were what weve come to expect from this type of film, neither less, nor more preposterous than those in the MI series.  The shame of it is that theres an interesting storyline in this movie that could have been expounded on had it not been for the directors tendency to bleed every second out of the ridiculous encounters between Cruise and either the drones or the Scavs.  The storyline is quite complicated and would require at least a second viewing - and probably more - in order to be fully comprehended.

I won't be watching it again, though.  There are simply too many of the action sequences that would have to be suffered through again and I don't feel like punishing myself in that manner.  What once caused me to marvel at how they're able to manufacture the special effects now has me yawning and wanting to get back to the underlying story.  Hint to Hollywood:  it aint special anymore if everybodys doing it.

I came across this movie while channel surfing. The little I saw piqued my interest enough to prompt me to want to see the full movie. I checked out the DVD version through the local city library system. Watching it prompted me to buy the Blu Ray version. And now, for the movie. A number of one-line descriptions I've seen that are meant to give potential viewers a basic idea of what the movie is about are inaccurate. There's a whole lot more to it than that. It is a "layered" production.  By that, I mean that seeing the movie for the first time lets the viewer pick up on the basic plot. Yet, most viewers will likely not pick up on numerous instances in the movie providing pieces key to a deeper understanding for what is really going on with plot and characters.  Further viewings will be revealing to most viewers, giving a lot of "ah-has!"  The visual imagery is dazzling (well worth a blu-ray), and the soundtrack will give your audio system a workout, no matter what audio format is used. The blu ray disc also has a number of informational clips on how the movie was made, which are valuable and interesting. That regarding the making of the movie (conception, production, direction, plot philosophy, etc) was illuminating, and if a viewer is having trouble figuring out certain aspects of what is going on within the movie, watching that clip will help to gain a complete understanding (as will listening to the director and actor commentary during the movie) of what is really going on.  As other reviewers have noted, it's not a perfect sci-fi movie.  At the same time, I think it has a lot to offer, and I recommend it without hesitation.

State of the art houses high in the clouds, desolate and emotive barren landscapes and a post-apocalyptic movie with future tech about clashing realities and the nature of memory. Very much a meta sci-fi offering and perhaps one of the very best in post cgi cinema revolution of its type.

The mix of the three main story leads in their character roles is superb ( Cruises character comes across great throughout) as is the stellar Spanish voice track and subs also I find.

Oblivion starts great with a snappy montage type intro explaining the techs (Jack Harper) pov, after which it maintains the intriguing dramatic tone as the story builds. Quite a number of scenes have a vignette advert quality about them, like the top dinner table and swim pool dream, with elements of a grand deodorant advert about it and by and largely they are seamlessly stitched together in the films narrative.

Slight spoilers: To the above, I found the films intriguing tone got broken abit in the above stylistic way from Jack and Julie arriving to the log house into the following drone shoot outs with some slight cliché injected into events, while still being good.

However then theres a cinematic bolt of lightning when the film dwells on Kurylenkos hero character and the romance with Cruises character abit and the film just goes up another level (also using its best music moments) in just summing up a profound type of notion at the heart of the movies emotion  alien abduction and character connection, whatever anyhow it goes someplace else in its narrative. One of the most pristine dramatic sequences in films of Cruises I have seen (& cinematically generally) and creates a great set up for the culminating section of the films finales.
Its a great story overall in Oblivion, with quite a lot of coincidence to its memory construct of reality that despite its apparent conclusion, a sequel could be very interesting and just as good in a different way too I would guess. All the same, this is one of the top films for ambitious modern sci-fi cinema.

I'm not normally a Tom Cruise fan. This movie came to me because I am an M83 fan, and the music spoke to me long before I even knew about this film. On one hand, I can tell you how many movies he stars in, I enjoy. This might be my second favorite after Vanilla Sky. His performance is outstanding. Though there is action, I never felt like he was attempting to be an action star, which is a better role for him, especially as he ages. It is when emotion hits him that he is at his best. That was why I loved Vanilla Sky so much, and like the other film, the single, short cameo of another great actor helped bring out his performance at the climax.

I thought the film was going to have its problems. I really did. The plot started making me angry as we got into Act 3. Why did the writer have to make the decisions they did to bring about the ending of the story? I usually see endings coming, and I should have with this one. But the way that it was executed was masterful. I might even end up buying the blu-ray of this so I can watch it with commentary and all that good stuff in the near future.

FORMAT: Blu-Ray + DVD + Digital HD + Ultra Violet
  UPC: 0-25192-17090-4
  RELEASED: 2013-08-06

TITLE:  Oblivion (2013)  PG-13  2:04:42
  Tom Cruise, Morgan Freeman, Olga Kurylenko, Andrea Riseborough
  Joseph Kosinski (Director)

  I think that most of the people who are bad mouthing this movie are doing so because they expect ALL "sci-fi" movies to be "action" movies. I think this movie, while it has a goodly amount of action, is primarily a thinking person's science fiction movie (as opposed to a "sci-fi" movie, which these days is nearly synonymous with fantasy). If you want to be spoon fed a lot of explosions, gunfights, high-tech gadgets and creepy-looking, murderous xenomorphs (i.e.aliens), then you will probably NOT enjoy this movie. However, if you don't mind paying attention to events as they unfold, and keeping track of said events from beginning to end, then you probably will enjoy this movie. I know that I thoroughly enjoyed it because it WASN'T your typical weakly-plotted, unscientific, action-oriented, "sci-fi" movie (think ANY of the Transformer movies). Is its science 100 percent accurate? No. But, it wasn't so GROSSLY inaccurate as to take me out of the plot, and make me ENTIRELY dismiss the premise of the movie. I found this film to be a welcome change of pace from most of the recent "sci-fi" movies, and I highly recommend it.

  See the other reviews for more detail and/or other opinions regarding the plot of the movie.

VIDEO:  2.39:1  Color  1080p  MPEG-4 AVC (35.9 Mbps)

  This movie features images that are very sharp, with great apparent depth, excellent shadow detail, and great contrast  and, they also possess a muted (and, sometimes, nearly monochromatic) color-palette that works very well with the tone of the source material. Fine detail is readily visible in all of the close-ups of faces, clothing, furnishings and machines  without any apparent edge-enhancement. Also, while there is some very mild banding on rare occasions (mainly, in the scene where Jack (Tom Cruise) uses his flashlight in the (now) subterranean library), there are no other anomalies to mar the image. Overall, this movie's picture quality is excellent  and, it should satisfy the VAST majority of viewers.

AUDIO:  DTS-HD Master Audio 7.1 (48 KHz, 24-bit)

  The sound quality and mix of the DTS-HD Master Audio 7.1 soundtrack is nearly reference quality. This soundtrack has most of the things that you want, sound-wise, in a movie; namely: very intelligible and well placed dialog, very deep bass in the front, side, rear and subwoofer channels, fairly active and mostly directional sound effects in ALL (i.e.front, side and rear) channels, ambient and environmental sounds that are effective in communicating the location of the on-screen setting and action, and well recorded music (that is utilized effectively in the front AND surround channels). Overall, the sound presentation for this movie should satisfy all but the very pickiest of listeners.

EXTRAS: Director's Commentary (also featuring Tom Cruise)
  Deleted Scenes
  Several 'Making Of' Type Videos
  Isolated Musical Score

  None of the extras were reviewed.

I love a film that surprises!  And this one does.  I can't believe I've never heard of it until now- especially with Tom Cruise and Morgan Freeman starring.  This is not like your average science fiction movie.  Earth's moon has been devastated by an alien species and while humans have won the war, our planet has apparently been damaged beyond repair.  People have all been moved to Titan, a moon around Saturn.  Two people have been left on earth to oversee the last 'mop up' jobs remaining on earth and we get to witness the last two weeks of their jobs until they, too, will finally get to move from the earth to their new paradise on Titan.  Only... things take a very unusual turn that makes both question.. just about everything they know.  I loved the entire story line- I never saw the twist coming which was brilliantly done.  I felt the shock right along with the characters and rejoiced in the end.  The only problem I had was the shabbiness of the drones.  They seemed to be made out of the cheapest, lightest plastic.  They way they bounced around belied the fearsome reputation they had.  And watching people be afraid of them was a little funny.  The other thing that needed just a little more work was the identity of the alien force- what were they and why did they need all that water??  lol.  But all around, kudos for a great storyline.  I enjoyed it a lot.  Just up the budget a little next time for special effects, ok?

Holy smokes. I was expecting to see a techy sci-fi film with some dumb plot point, but I was so absolutely stunned by the film. I was drawn in from the beginning due to the production design of the film and the lead characters, but I didn't realize just how much of a gem this film is. It's a cinematic achievement for 21st century film - I really don't know why the critics don't see it. Perhaps the film is a bit too deep and complex for some people? This is by far one of the most intelligent, well-thought-out, intricately designed films I have seen a LONG time. It's a beautiful film with its own share of tragic moments and joy-inducing sequences. TL:DR: This is the kind of film that you want to buy, not just rent. It's just simply beautiful. It's a must see. You will be moved.

One of the very few movies with Tom Cruise that I enjoy.  A decent sci-fi flick with an amazing score.

Please note I viewed this on a Samsung KS8000 series 55 SUHD TV through a Samsung UBD K8500 player. I am really only assessing the image as I have the TV wired into my stereo as opposed to a home theater.

To buy, or not to buy, that is the question  This is a solid 4k release, although it is not mind blowing or reference material. Probably worth $15 on eBay if you are a big fan of the movie.

The movie itself is a solid action/sci-fi mind-bender that doesn't fall into the typical patterns of traditional big-budget blockbusters, although it could be considered a bit of a rip-off of the underrated Duncan Jones classic 'Moon' from the decade earlier. The 4k UHD release features solid image detail, although it never reaches the 'wow' point. The colors are stronger than on the blu ray, although skin tones seem a bit overly pink. Additionally the color palette in the movie itself is fairly limited with stark landscapes and dreary underground bunker life so color enhancements for UHD have limited opportunities to realize their potential.

What it comes down to is whether or not the 4k UHD represents a significant upgrade over the blu ray. It is an improvement overall, but maybe not worth replacing your already excellent blu ray if you are not a huge fan of the film.

Oblivion is a somewhat confusing science fiction film featuring clones, drones, aliens and post-apocalyptic conspiracies. A romance has been thrown in, as well. Tom Cruise and Morgan Freeman star the main protagonists.

The plot is set on Earth after a devastating war between humans and aliens known as scavengers or scavs. Weirdly, the aliens are on the planet surface, while the humans live on a space station known as the Tet. The main hero, Jack (who works for Tet), discovers that his memories have been wiped out and that something is seriously wrong about the whole post-apocalyptic scenario. Supposedly radioactive zones turn out to be safe, clones of Jack and his co-pilot show up, and Jack's own wife (believed to be dead) is rescued from a mysterious space module. The mission recorder tells a shocking story which will make Jack question everything, including his very identity, and once again put the fate of humanity in the balance

It's not really a bad film, but the story (including the ending) is difficult to comprehend unless you're paying really good attention, or cheat by reading the Wikipedia entry. Well, the ending is actually incomprehensible anyway. Be that as it may, I will nevertheless give this post(?)apocalyptic fantasy the OK rating  three stars.

Generally I feel this is a good selection to round out a night of science fiction indulgence. As a piece of fine art - it is not that. The actors are believable, set design is impeccable, costuming does not upset the immersion, technological assumptions and styling likewise fit the stylistic flow of the film.

It is a thin feeling movie in regards to the emotional bond an audience member might make with the characters. There is alot of convenience as well. I don't want to say "contrivance." I just think there's a bit too much convenience in the film. Especially noted by the monuments that happen to be visible (height and structural integrity taken into consideration) but especially significant with the empire state building.
stories are told because there's something about the events that are worth telling. Even a seemingly boring story is told because of the significance to the storyteller.

Still, I feel the experience is worth it to any science fiction fan looking for entertainment. Someone who is not easily offended by less-than-stellar science, plot, or character development, etc.

A dystopian future where an alien race has destroyed Earth's moon and made war on the human race for possession of the planet. As a result, the human race used nuclear weapons to defeat the extra-terrestrial enemy but poisoned the planet in the process.

This is where we pick up the story. Jack Harper (Tom Cruise) is Tech-49 whose task is to keep drones in the air protecting the giant hydro-rigs that suck up seawater to make fusion reaction so the remainder of the human race in the "Tet", a giant orbiting spacestation, can move to Titan, Jupiter's largest moon to begin again. Then, out of nowhere, an ancient space shuttle lands with the woman that haunts Jack's dreams.

I was surprised by the numerous twists and turns in this film. The tech is cool, the special effects are very good as if the ravaged, desert landscape. The action sequences are excellent. Cruise does a fine job in his role as does Andrea Riseborough who plays "Victoria", Tech-49's communication link with the Tet and partner. Olga Kurylenko gives a wooden performance as the "woman in his dreams" but doesn't detract significantly from the overall production.

This is good sci-fi that will surprise you as the film progresses. I enjoyed this film immensely and I think most sci-fi fans will too. This is a first-rate movie, five stars.

This movie has some of the most stunning visuals in the history of film and has an outstanding soundtrack that often sets the mood perfectly for each scene.  Yes, the movie has some plot holes, but don't almost all fictional movies?  The acting is solid and beyond some of the gaps in the story line and similarity to other movies, it really sets forth the question of our existence and what makes us human.  It may never be recognized as one of the classics or greatest movies of all time, but it is definitely worth watching it its entirety (i.e., not on TV with commercial breaks) to gain a appreciation for the movie.

Pretty typical Tom Cruise story line - you have to overlook some of the implausibility and weaknesses but it is action and romance in a great plot - I really enjoyed it and actually watched it twice. Even my wife liked it and she is not a Science Fiction fan. The scenery is fantastic. The music (M83 - Susanne Sundfor) fits well.

It's usually a waste of time to write negative reviews, but seeing as the film made me waste time with an empty promise here goes . . .

What a desperate film. This has all the surface gloss of a great SF film and some of the other ingredients, but somehow they don't all come together properly. The central mystery of the film is for the characters, all revolving around the Cruise axis, to prove they have character too (they don't), and hopefully come up with a story by the end of the film.

If you haven't fallen asleep, by the end of the film you will discover a decent story has finally emerged, but before that point you really want to stop the whole thing. Where Rise of the Planet of the Apes is a great film, this is not. Rise, has the surface glamour, but more importantly, it also has a good story, proper plot development, characters with credible depth, humour and action.

It would be all too easy to lay the blame on Cruise, but he's not bad in this film. (Morgan Freeman is bad. Gravel Voice doesn't equal Gravitas, it gets tiring seeing him typecast so formulaically.) The connections just aren't there. There was no connection between Cruise and his teammate, and when he discovers his dreammate, that too fails to convince. The one good relationship is between Victoria (teammate) and her boss - the feigned equanimity was done very well.
One of the most visually stunning blu rays I have ever seen.

Fantastic movie with stunning visuals. When I was a kid I dreamt and hoped movies would look and feel this good. The film has a very 70s sci fi feel and artistic direction to it (think Heavy Metal magazine)...which is my favorite type of sci fi look and atmosphere. The story and twist is pretty awesome as well and I have to admit Tom Cruise as well as Morgan Freeman, Olga Kurylenko, and Andrea Riseborough did a fantastic job at creating emotion and suspense. And last but not least...the amazingly unbelievable soundtrack by M83's Anthony Gonzalez teaming up with Joseph Trapanese (Tron Legacy Soundtrack). The end credits song...cleverly titled "Oblivion" is my fave off of the soundtrack. The song is very epic with a haunting but yet melancholic melody and provides an outstanding vocal performance by the talented Susanne Sundfr. Great visuals, great story, great twists, great acting, and great music = a spectacular epic sci fi extravaganza!

Although the premise behind OBLIVION has potential the result is too flawed and derivative to have much of an impact. This is movie-making by the numbers, and its all too easy to guess whats about to happen from one scene to the next. And as a consequence of this, when the denouement arrives its rather ho-hum. Its also marred by a horribly portentous voiceover. But it looks impressive, and Cruise uses this obvious star-vehicle to reasonably good effect and performs well, as usual. This is SF the Hollywood blockbuster way, which means its heavy on visuals and action and light on story and character. But if you can accept it for what it is its not a terrible film and is more entertaining than it perhaps has a right to be.

One of the best Science Fiction films I've seen, with a solid script, acting, and plot.  Reminds me of "Aliens" in that it's a rock solid drama set in a Science Fiction landscape.  The visuals are fantastic, and the director is genuinely gifted in that he is the one who not only envisioned all the imagery, buildings, vehicles, etc, but actually sketched them onto paper years before the film project, and the sketches look exactly as what you see in the movie.  I watched this movie 'cold' having not seen the trailer or movie poster.  I think the box covers and movie posters showing Morgan Freeman spoil the plot.  There was a movie poster with Tom Cruz alone in front of a destroyed bridge, this should be the only image shown to future viewers of the film.

After watching the film, I then went online and was shocked to see the film was not properly recognized in the press.  Could be the Morgan Freeman poster or trailers spoiled the plot slightly for many folks.  This film is a bit like the "Sixth Sense" in that people should not know too much about the story before seeing the film.

Plot and acting aside (which were fantastic) Tom Cruise in true form is actually sitting on the cliffs seen in the film -- no special effects there.  (He also scaled one of the tallest buildings in the world for Mission Impossible, help only by ropes.)

In closing, saw this 'cold' without seeing a trailer or poster, and enjoyed it tremendously.

Tommy, Tommy, Tommy... you were so close to having an excellent movie here. Overall, this movie is watchable, but it looses it's logic. By the end you'll have to question the whole premise. Other explanations of the circumstances could have been found and would not have precluded the premise of the movie. I won't spoil the plot for you, but let me just say that a science fiction writer was not employed in the making of this movie. Again, the film is enjoyable enough for a viewing, but in the end falls short of making sense, and finally paying off. We don't even get to see this war to which they refer. Also, the music is pathetic keyboard junk. Absolute garbage synth music. Why spend a hundred million dollars just to skimp on the music. You do know all the classical music ever made is in the public domain right? I think the music alone limits the number of views I can tolerate to: one. Again, you might enjoy it, but don't purchase it. Get it from your library instead.
ALL'S WELL

Judging a film is a very tricky process because a lot of it is subjective. The only thing that can be commented upon is the craftsmanship and the craftsmanship of this film is masterful.

This is one sci-fi film that captures a very different tone than most others in the genre.
The story is built around and constantly evolves with the the characters (which you can count on one hand) so the film is really substantive.
The cinematography, the camera work, the stunts, the music, the CGI, all of these formal elements of filmmaking are handled with incredible skill and harmony.
Tom Cruise's performance and his dedication to do his own stunts is the defining characteristic of what makes this sci-fi story so enjoyable and personal. You are always in the middle of the action and can see the character engage in the action as if you were right next to him.

I love this film for being as imaginative as it is and for the amazing handling of the art form to make this story as enjoyable as it is.

This is my favorite recent Sci Fi movie.  It is a throwback to the golden age of Sci Fi when writers worked with a blank page and took their imaginations boldly to new frontiers.  The lack of imagination in today's Sci Fi, where studios turn out the umpteenth Star Trek or Star Wars movie...is just sad.  Here is a movie that has a concise plot, does a good job of filling in the back story, presents pretty novel plot and comes to a pretty dramatic climax in a couple of hours.  It is practically a lost art to turn out one movie that achieves all that.  While I am certainly not a fan of Tom Cruise the person, he is a good actor and turns in a very good performance, as do the supporting cast members.

A surprisingly excellent movie, but the ending was very disappointing. After discovering the horrible truth about the alien's victory, the director creates a wonderful buildup to the conclusion. At the supreme moment, Tom and Morgan are getting ready to blow the alien's craft into atoms and rid the world of these interstellar parasites, when Sally tells Tom that she created him and that she is his God. Instead of Tom's character telling her "to go to hell" or even "here's Johnny," he just says "forget you Sally." Surly, someone on the movie set must have mentioned how lame that response was. For me, it was a big let down, because I would have told Sally to stick it where the sun doesn't shine.

Though I'm not a fan of most Tom Cruise's movies, I made an exception and actually bought this one after a Netflix viewing. It's got a great plot with a nice twist at the end of the story, both of which prevent this flick from becoming just another Tom Cruise vehicle showcasing his chiseled good (?) looks. The cinematography is wonderful, full of dizzyingly airborne perspectives of the Earth's surface. The cameo appearance of a famous african-american actor (spoilers!) as a seeming villain who turns out to be a heroic, self-sacrificing figure works well (for once). The sci-fi technology is nicely done CGI imagery that's not too over the top. The story's premise is also believable: this eerie post-apocalyptic world is sparsely populated and its redeemers win the day in a plausible and convincing manner. All in all, this is a visually stunning and intellectually satisfying flick... even with Tom Terrific as the lead.

Oblivion is one my favorite science fiction movies.  The story is a unique and engaging tale of a few people fighting to save mankind from annihilation, with (of course) Tom Cruise in the pivotal lead role.  It has a small cast, each one of whom delivers a flawless, very convincing performance.  Location shooting in Iceland provides an incredible vista of stunning locations.  The use of special effects is seamless, though you know they're there when you're looking at places and vehicles that do not exist in today's world.

As the film unfolds, the main theme shifts toward emphasis on a romance involving Tom Cruise and another members of the cast.  (I'm trying to dance around spoilers here.)  Insightful human psychology and the intricacies of our personalities play a huge role in this film.  There's still enough high-speed action for enthusiasts for SF action movies, and not a single frame of it is pointless filler; no padded-out chases of unlikely vehicles or confusing battle scenes.  And not a single plot element that depends on the Hand of God or Pure Dumb Luck to rescue the hero from an impossible situation.  The good guys accomplish what they accomplish with their own ingenuity, foresight, and courage.

The voice-over commentary by Tom Cruise and director Joseph Kosinski is nearly as much fun as the movie itself; do be sure to watch it along with the production extras.  You'll learn about how Kosinski's dedication to his story led to his friendship with Tom Cruise and the making of the film.

There's a little bit of gee-whiz alien super technology and the aliens' basic motivation is technically silly, but neither of those really bothers me while watching this film.  I'm a retired aerospace engineer, and most of what you see makes me think, "Yup, given the time, a talented staff of engineers, and the budget to cover it all, I could built that."

My husband is a big sci fi fan and chose this movie. The five stars is his review. He liked that the plot was unpredictable and there were big surprises at the end. I liked that too, but I would have given it 3-4 stars because most of the movie was slow going until the surprising things started happening in the last 30-45 minutes.  Still, we did talk about it afterward and later the next day, which is saying something. For most movies, there is not much to discuss afterward.

Understated, subtle, layered and elegant, this movie is a rare combination of mystery, action, sympathetic characters and lasting beauty. It's a post-apocalyptic movie that leaves you hopeful about humans. At the same time, it shows that some humans will always prefer the oblivion of fantasy to the reality of a hope you may have to struggle for.

I'm not sure, despite the outstanding visual beauty of this film, that the movie would have worked if the main characters, starting with Tom Cruise's character, hadn't been so immediately accessible with the appealing combination of vulnerability, strength, intelligence, and resourcefulness. Not to mention the authority and credibility that Morgan Freeman brought to his character.

Director, producer, etc.,  Joseph Kosinski, did a fabulous job of putting all the pieces together and making all the right choices, from cast to location and everything in between

This is that rarest of post-apocalyptic movies: rewatchable.

P.S. The commentary by Cruise and Kosinski was one of the better ones I've heard. It actually added depth and layers to the movie, guaranteeing a better viewing experience the second time around.

So many remarkable coincidences in this movie and with my life as I wrote in my journal after watching it numerous times.

Character's name is Jack, so is mine.- Jack displays a most independent free will.

Jack's memory has been wiped clean, so has mine been drastically degraded due to a brain tumor causing numerous seizures.

Jack loves EARTH and its natural wonders - me, too!

He even loves playing music from old ancient record albums, and so do I.

Just prior to one of these record albums starting to play, I could hear an owl hooting in Jack's beloved natural setting. I so love owls! I heard one in Yosemite National Park just the other night.

When Jack wakes up at his gorgeous natural paradise-on-earth, a PEACE DOVE can be heard clearly. I love doves.

Jack has powerful dreams that he has a difficult time understanding. Don't we all?

Jack is a pilot as am I. Of course, I have never flown anything quite as sophisticated as that ship of Jack's!

Jack talks at the end of this movie about having a soul and the power of LOVE. I think of these powerful concepts all of the time.

The statements made in this movie about winning the war and contaminating the planet go right along with my fears.

He visits an old library that has been destroyed in the war, but there are still many old books in this library. Jack takes one when he leaves this library. He displays a love of libraries, and so do I love libraries which is where I am typing this from right now.

He saves a stuffed gorilla toy and takes it with him to his favorite Yosemite-like natural setting. I so love Yosemite and spend much time there currently. I have numerous very small stuffed animals in my tent which remind me of nature.

Morgan Freeman is wearing the exact same sun glasses that I wore when I backpacked the 230 mile long John Muir Trail many years ago. I have not seen these sun glasses since then.

There are many more coincidences that I will not bore you with at this time. It is a fascinating movie, and I would highly recommend it. I suggest that you see the Alex Jones review that he does of this movie via "THE ALEX JONES SHOW." I did a search on "youtube.com" and came up with that review. We so worship technology, and yet it can get us into so much trouble which I think is one of the underlying themes of this movie.

After helping to build 100 B-1B bombers for Rockwell International and the Military-Industrial-Corporate-Corrupt-Capitalist-Megamachine  (MICCCM), I know that this potential trouble that we create for humanity is REAL. When I tried to learn the destructive capability of each of these bombers carrying multiple-warhead hydrogen bombs in each of the three weapons bays, it was denied to me due to a "NEED TO KNOW" protocol. That was critical information that we ALL needed to know so we would wake up during the night after having "OBLIVION-TYPE" nightmares! Unfortunately, the only format in which we are allowed to know anything of true "OBLIVION" potential is via a fictional movie like this one and many others. May we all come to our PEACEFUL senses before this movie becomes non-fiction. In the NAME OF "THE PRINCE OF PEACE"  I pray...

Thank you Amazon for making this avenue of communication available to us.

This film is so good that I have to believe it's got to be one of the 10 best sci-fi movies ever made.  The acting and drama is topnotch, of course.  But the plot and special effects and unique, original sci-fi zeitgeist of Oblivion is just remarkable and mesmerizing.  Not only this, but this movie is non-stop action, and you can never guess where it's going and what's going to happen next.  Just pure fun and intelligent, visual stimulating entertainment.  And it's even has an incredibly sensitive love story woven into its plot.  And yes the music is great, too.  Tom Cruise is at his best here, just like he is in Edge of Tomorrow and all his sci-fi films.  I've seen this film twice now.  A third viewing is coming soon, I know!

Far into the future some man and woman are perched in the sky in some space age home. Their job is to fix robots that fly around these power plants that are sucking earth's water up to be used as energy in the mother ship somewhere near Saturn--where all the other humans are. The couple's job is almost done. And then they get to go to Saturn. Apparently there was a war with some creatures that destroyed the moon. So after the moon was destroyed earth was off its axis and natural disasters occurred altering earth and making it uninhabitable. But still under attack by these creatures man almost destroyed the planet by using nuclear weapons to defeat 98% of the creatures.

Sounds like a cool plot. But the problem wasn't in the beginning, middle or end. It was in the details. I cannot share those with you as it would ruin the movie for you but at some point in this movie there is a strange twist that makes sense at first. It is easy to get what has been happening, what is happening on earth/to earth. But then there is another twist involving the forbidden "radiation zones" that makes absolutely no sense to me. I mean, yes, I know why there were these forbidden zones, yes. But the other aspects of that. And the aspects of when this guy is approaching the mother ship--the switching back and forth from/to the space ships approaching the mother ship. I didn't get it. Maybe it is because the characters were always in a whisper. I dunno. Maybe I couldn't hear them even though I had the volume level at 35. Or maybe it just didn't make sense. But there is a huge hole in this movie that if I just shrugged it off I actually didn't miss anything to wrap up the movie with as the ending kinda made sense nonetheless. Anyway if you spent too much time thinking about it it would bug you in trying to piece it together. So I just didn't.

It gets five stars for being a good sci-fi movie all around and 6 stars for plot twists. It also gets five stars for being orders of magnitude better than junk sci-fi like Interstellar. It gets 4 stars for story and dialog. In the end, when Sally says she is his God, Tom Cruise's character should respond, "No Sally, you're the Devil!". Instead he says, "F-you, Sally" which is crass, unimaginative and uncreative. What could have been a legendary movie line falls on the ear with a splat. The story suffers from insufficient background of the human survivor colony. The survivor colony is not properly set up for the amount it is used. There is a significant amount of participation from the colonists which begs for more information about them. Other than a bit about Morgan Freeman's character, everyone else is unknown. None of this detracts from this being an excellent sci-fi film.

It seems that movies Nicholas Cage likes to do I simply hate. I know that any Cage movie isn't worth my time because our tastes, what he makes and what I watch, are irreconcilable. Exactly the opposite with Tom Cruise and SciFi movies. Minority Report, Edge of Tomorrow I really enjoyed, and Oblivion is another great SciFi movie. If you liked those you will enjoy this one. Like the other two, there is a great story with some genuine emotional content to go along with the amazing visuals and the pretty package of the movie. The soundtrack is good too. Check it out.

While a great book is a story told through words, a great movie is a story told through pictures. Oblivion goes beyond just the visuals, however. The sound effects blended with the score by MEighty-three are simply powerful; I got chills near the end once again. Some say the critics missed this one. I agree. It is my theory that, in this day and age, in a sci-fi epic where the world is destoryed, it must be blamed on "Global Warming."  And if we humans fought  a world-wide war against alien invaders with our own nuclear weapons, then all life on earth would be wiped out by radiation for eternity. Thankfully the film makers in this case refused to sucumb to such tiring "Polictical Correctness." Just ask yourself how in the world Elysium got four stars! Really,,,? I'll say to the critics what Jack Harper last said to Sally and just leave it at that...

Tom Cruise cranks out another top role as Jack Harper the astronaut turned high-tech futuristic pilot/soldier in this intriguing sci-fi adventure which features excellent special effects and great supporting performances from Andrea Riseborough (Victoria), Olga Kurylenko (Julia Harper), Melissa Leo (Sally) and Morgan Freeman (Malcolm Beech - a supporting character, not a co-star in spite of the billing he gets). The film probes the essence of human nature and the dynamics of interpersonal relationships in a post apocalyptic earth after a war with alien invaders. It does this well enough, revealing not too much nor too little to maintain interest as the story unfolds, while keeping the focus on entertainment. Great ending. Enjoy.

The problem: this movie is supposed to appeal to sci-fi lovers. Well, if you are a sci-fi lover (SPOILER ALERT) you recognize elements of Alien (running into a ship in the middle of nowhere), Matrix (all those clones lined up), Independence Day (aliens coming to suck the Earth of resources, being destroyed with a planted A-bomb), Star Trek I (being sucked into a large alien ship) I would even reference Star Wars (Death Star), but Star Wars is not really sci-fi, as we all know. After a while, all those rip-offs become distracting.

Oblivion is a good movie it just takes awhile for the story to really get to where it's going.  I liked the post apolocaliptic take on the future.  The movie is really slow paced and will turn off a lot of mainstream action viewers used to more excitement.  Our society is filled with TV shows and movies with non stop action with little to no story development! The live action Transformers movies anyone.  So I applaud the director for taking the time to setup a riveting story.  Some of the visuals in the film are amazing and will stick with you after the film. I liked how ultimately Tom's character Jack learned to appreciate the little things that life had to offer, music, books a tranquil environment.  Which was the basis for the humanity inside to wakeup.

The film does have some nice twists and is predictable in the end, but I still found the movie worth watching.  In supporting parts I thought both Morgan Freeman and Nikolaj Coster-Waldeu (aka Jamie Lannister) were very good.  Andrea Riseborougl seemed to be very robotic in the film but was easy on the eyes.  Tom Cruises character seemed pretty bright in the film but you would have thought he would have tried to capture a Scav similar to what Charlton Heston tried to do in the Original Omega Man to learn about them instead of just blasting them on sight.  He should have known something was up when the drones started shooting the escape pods.  I won't give anymore away than that.

You really get a sense of how desolate and isolated the world has become in the movie.  It reminded me of WALL-E in a strange way.  Olga Kurylenko did a nice job as Julia Jack's wife in the film trying to piece together his past a lot of the flashbacks slow down the film even further.  I thought the film was worth watching but it is definitely not for people with ADD or who want instant action all the way through.  I would steer those viewers towards Edge of Tomorrow another newer Tom Cruise Sci Fi movie instead.  This film deliberately goes at a slow pace.  If you don't have the patience for a movie with a slow beginning this is definitely not the movie for you.

I have to say, this movie surprised me when I first saw it. That doesn't happen too often but I'm usually glad when it does because Hollywood can get something right once in a while. The story behind Oblivion started out as a comic book/graphic novel idea that was left to sit while the author(s) worked on other projects (if that's incorrect feel free to set me straight). If you're a sci-fi buff you'll notice a few homages to other works, but I felt this story stood on its own fairly well for the most part.

The visuals are spectacular; much of it was shot in the volcanic landscapes of Iceland. Having said that, I felt the score not only fit the movie perfectly, but was also quite possibly the best part of the film. It had both a retro feel to it but also sounded futuristic at the same time; like it was a classic 80s film that took place in the future. There's a couple twists that, for me, broke several SF clichs and didn't take too drastic a turn that would've damaged the pacing and plot.

My criticisms of Oblivion were relatively minor but I'll mention a few of them anyway: Things such as why wasn't Jack under closer supervision by the Tet or, since he's expendable, why allow him to override the drones' functions, or any of the technology for that matter? I also don't at all buy such a drastic effect from destroying the moon. There are others but there were very few WTF moments IMO, which is probably one of the main reasons this movie surprised me as much as it did.

I give this movie a solid 4 stars because I'm a fan of the genre and felt every element had something to praise. Oblivion is family friendly and isn't overlong like many films these days; why not give it a shot.

I rate this movie at four stars because, compared to a lot of the sci-fi drivel out there, this movie is much better.  Both the acting and the action were good to excellent.  On the down side, however, although at first view the plot seemed plausible, retrospectively, the plot had many gaps.  Why use humans to extract earth's natural resources when the aliens' robots seemed to be sufficiently advanced to be able to do so?  Why did an oasis untouched by the aliens exist? Why should we believe that Julia could love one of Jack's clones to say nothing of two of his clones? On the whole, though, as with any good sci-fi, the movie left me wondering, "Could this happen?  And if so, how might it happen?" To me, good sci-fi always leaves me with something to think about.

Oblivion is a somewhat enjoyable combination of various sci-fi and post-apocalyptic dystopian future plot lines from across the media spectrum.  There are aspects of Fallout 3 (ex. the collection of assorted junk that is left behind, the bobblehead, and drone repair), Star Wars (the clone army), Star Trek (the Borg-esque AI), The Matrix (the imagery of a field of people growing inside the "ship"), and the "aliens" look like the Predator.  There were some original plot twists that could have been exploited in a more interesting and/or an in-depth manner.  It would have been a solid 3 1/2 star movie if not for the ending.

****SPOILERS****
The ending was irritating and made me feel like the editor and/or studio just gave up.  For example, where did the daughter come from?  How is it that 52 was just as empathetic as 49 and had the same apparent lingering memories as 49?  Was 49 not that unique?  And the voice-over dialogue, who is asking if she sees him when she looks at the girl, the original Jack, 49, 52, or some other clone?

When I hear the title, I keep thinking of "Edge of Tomorrow" (aka "Live. Die. Repeat."), but that was a better movie. This one is so-so, but good enough for a movie-night viewing. Much of it is predictable, but in a good way. But, it could have been done in a shorter timeframe, or maybe more twists could have been thrown in.

I'm torn about whether to review the film or this actual product, but I'll settle for just reviewing the product you're spending money on. If you want to read a review of the film, do an internet search and see what critics have said. My opinion of the film: if you loved TRON: Legacy, then you'll feel right at home here since it's the same director. The film is visually beautiful, the music is great, and it can be thought-provoking. It doesn't really break new ground, but the twists and turns in the plot are fun and interesting, and the film plays on a lot of established scifi tropes, which may be good or bad depending on your personal preference.

The product is great, as it allows you to watch the film in any way you want- traditional DVD player, Blu-ray, digital copy. I haven't delved into any of the special features, but the film itself is crystal clear as it should be for a high-definition format.

Basically, you're only buying this movie if you liked the film in the first place. And if you did like it, you need to buy it in high-definition since that's the way it was filmed and the details that only HD can bring out make the film that much more enjoyable to watch.

Wow this is a unique & strange film.

 Basic Plot: Weird aliens from this orbiting pyramid spaceship run most of the Earth, & Tom Cruise is a Soldier-Airman flying Cop like actor on the world stage who flies around in this exotic aviation machine that sort of looks like a mix between a plane & a helicopter policing his sector.

 If you are a fan of other sci fi franchises like "Star Trek", "Terminator", "Star Wars", "Aliens", "Conan", "2001", "Game of Thrones", & others you might like this movie.

Cruise and his girlfriend live in this high in the sky house where they report to the aliens onboard the pyramid spaceship.  Very weird and exotic movie with good special effects and a very mind blowing ending.  I enjoyed this film and love Tom Cruise and Morgan Freeman in all the work they do.  And Cruise looks amazing for his age.  Thumbs up, & B+ for Oblivion.

Beautiful visuals are matched with a somewhat mediocre story, but the whole seemed better than I expected. I wasn't counting on too much based on things I had read about this movie, but I decided to give it a chance anyway. I found that the visual elements were far more stunning than I expected. The future inhabited by the two main characters is bleak, the world appears to have been destroyed by an attempted alien invasion. There are feral human saboteurs that these two try to overcome in order to accomplish their mission, but not all is as it appears. Morgan Freeman gives a great performance, and Tom Cruise plays the science fiction hero as he does so well.  Beautiful location shots and excellent CGI blend together to make a movie as breathtaking in its own way as the Lord of the Rings films. There are also a number of nice special features on the DVD that go into the making of the film and its effects.

Liking all things Science Fiction I gave this movie a second viewing after purchasing it for my Science Fiction collection. I'm not a professional movie reviewer just a person who likes these types of movies. I enjoyed the movie and think other sci-fi buffs would as well.

Such potential, and yet such large plot holes.  What's become of large SF movies lately?

For example, Transcendence was off to a great start, then jumped the rails and ended poorly.

Oblivion never gained traction as a story, Live Die Repeat was a violent joke of a film, and Lucy pulled up lame well before the finish line.

While Interstellar had its issues, it ended strong and is possibly the best SF movie of the last year.

I do want to mention The Europa Report and Gravity.

Gravity is the "Speed" of SF films (although it does have its positive points -- Gravity, that is, not Speed), while The Europa Report is one of those movies, like Pandorum, or Solaris, which grows on you over time.

When Tom Cruise finds another SF film as intelligent as Minority Report, or another role in a fantasy as rich as Legend, I'm all in.

Until then, I'm hoping he won't settle for any more films like Oblivion.

Honestly, I'd rather have a sequel to Knight And Day over this film.

Even 13-year old geeks had to be laughing at Oblivion, and who can blame them?

As a previous viewer said: This movie delivers. Let's face it, if you like sci fi and watch it a lot, you are going to end up seeing the same plots over and over. I get used to it, I like sci fi and I watch it for the plots...mostly. But when I come across that rare sci fi that not only has a good plot, but tells it really really well, I've just have to say something. And Oblivion delivers. The acting is phenomenal (well what did we expect coming from this cast?), the sets are beautiful and the story is creative and told well. I became emotionally invested in the outcome of the movie, and to me, that's what counts. Five stars.

Given the polarisation of popular opinion voiced in previous reviews, we settled down to watch this movie on Christmas afternoon with open minds, hoping for the best but half expecting disappointment. I'm happy to say that the former sentiment definitely won the day.

Tom Cruise plays his usual monolithic self as a repair-man for drones protecting vast machines against marauding Scavenger survivors as the machines suck the planet dry to provide fusion energy for the last bastion of mankind on Titan following a war with `the Scavengers' which left the moon destroyed and the Earth ruined. Or at least that is what he thinks he's doing.

It is difficult to elaborate further on the gradually unveiled truth without spoilers but it isn't really that hard to second guess the plot if you have a decent grounding in science fiction; it is not complicated and there's nothing startlingly original in any of the individual themes or their treatment. The whole film does, however, merge this potpourri of standard sci-fi plot devices into a fairly coherent whole. There is much either blatant plagiarism from or reverential hat-tipping to (depending on your point of view) almost every science fiction film & TV series since the 1970's and there are some gaping plot holes (try to keep track of the elusive flight recorder from the Odyssey if you can) but there's plenty of really cool hardware to keep the interest of our inner teenager and some excellent 70's music.

The film is visually stunning; not in an obvious flash-bang way but more the product of careful and consistent design and as a consequence, the whole experience is immersive and neatly conceived. Yes, there are silly bits, plot holes, continuity oddities and, I suspect, deliberately corny bits of dialogue but that doesn't stop it being a creditable effort at producing something different in a totally oversaturated movie genre. As with most Cruise offerings, sit back, turn off those higher cognitive functions and enjoy the ride - it is really quite a good film (although the Blu-ray case is very silly).

I waited many months until Oblivion was available to rent for under five dollars rather than buy.  The wait was worth it!  This is an amazing movie.  Oblivion and Edge of Tomorrow are two of the best movies that I have seen in years and both have Cruise as the lead actor.  Both movies are incredibly smart and unpredictable.  Obilivion is not like Cruise's flat War of the Worlds.  The nemesis is much more intelligent containing multiple smart hooks that surprise the viewer until the end.  Cruise does a great job acting and is one of the only aging a-listers that can still carry a great performance (unlike Brad Pitt, Mel Gibson, John Travolta, and others who seem to have grown complacent and big-headed). Oblivion is better than the preview indicates.  I thought that Morgan Freeman was going to end up being the bad guy, but the real enemy is surprising and complex.  The error of War of the Worlds with Tom Cruise (and other sci-fi movies) is that the nemesis doesn't have a personality and is too general in its scope, but in this movie it is very unique.  At only one point did I think the plot line started to meander when the clones started to arrive and I thought that movie would drift into weirdness, but then it made sense as the plot continued to unfold, and then made perfect sense at the end.  A sci-fi movie is best when it makes the fiction seem plausible and gives answers to questions at the end of the movie while keep the viewer trying to answer that question throughout the movie.  Cast: five stars, Plot: five stars, Cinematography: five stars, Love story: five stars.  The movie also contains a lot of hints at potential globalist plans for the future of America. I believe that movies are often used as predictive programming by the elite.  What does the blown up Super Bowl Stadium in 2017 mean?  What do all of the numbers mean?  In closing, I would definitely rent this movie, and could even buy.  So rare is it these days to find a movie that I would like to watch more than once.  Then, I would rent Edge of Tomorrow after it as both are excellent and both contain uber-fresh sci-fi plots lines that will keep you guessing until the end.

You won't find much that's new in this movie if you're a dedicated sci-fi fan. Oblivion fairly raids everything from Silent Running and Planet of the Apes through Total Recall and all the way to more recent fare such as Moon. I think the movie would have turned out better if the director had chosen one or two themes from one or two of its influences and developed those themes more fully. As it is, Oblivion feels more like 5 unfinished movies rather than 1 finished movie.

The visual style is truly original and a refreshing change from most sci-fi over the last 20 years. The director comments that, after the original Alien premiered in 1979, sci-fi movies moved towards dark and shadowy visual styles. Oblivion sparkles with whites, off-whites, and grays--the box art on the DVD cover gives you a good sense of the movie's look. The problem is, the art design and production design don't communicate any kind of strong view or outlook. You always get the feeling in classics such as 2001 and Blade Runner that directors Kubrick and Scott have an interest in their characters and that they're using their sets and visuals to express a mood and a theme. Oblivion fails to communicate that same sense of purpose. Consequently, it leaves you cold.

The most memorable thing about this movie is its "drones:" sphere-shaped robots that fly around and decimate enemy targets with the firepower of small battleships. The drones look great, their flight patterns show great imagination on the part of the moviemakers, and the wide range of sound effects they produce is truly astounding.

As for the acting...Tom Cruise is beginning to look a little too old to be starring in sci-fi actioners. At the very least, he shouldn't be in the lead role. He does well here, but he isn't especially involved. Nor does he generate any real sympathy for the character he plays. Olga Kurylenko and Andrea Riseborough are both competent actresses, but they seem to have been chosen more for their fashion-model good looks rather than for their acting abilities. They're both striking visual presences but so are statues. Finally, Morgan Freeman looks very cool in his shades. However, he doesn't have much of a role so any Freeman fans will find this film to be disappointing.

"Oblivion" manages to carve out a relatively original premise, which arrives near the end of the movie, and presents itself as a surprise, not unlike the surprise ending of "Planet of the Apes", although it creeps up on you over the last 20 minutes, with some thin clues showing up from the middle onward. With only two characters on screen for most of the movie, the dialogue is not scintillating, but then, that becomes part of the clue to the final reveal. In truth, from about 10 minutes in, you get that itch in the back of your mind which says, things are not what they seem. The problem is that what they seem is so unlike our normal world that we don't know what to make of that itch. It maybe the kind of itch which Kevin McCarthy felt when he returns to his home town, and some of his neighbors don't seem right.
There is a fair amount of "quoting" from similar "survival films" such as "The Omega Man" and "I am Legend". The similarity to those movies adds to the surprise, since the outcome is so different. The effects and scenery are "clean", since the moonlike landscape, filmed in Iceland, is all real. This may be what is often called a "hard" sci-fi tale, which, being also apocalyptic, will also appeal to a wide audience. I would rate it not quite as good as "Elysium" but better than "Ender's Game". I think the best recent film of this style was Ridley Scott's "Prometheus".

I avoided seeing this movie in theaters because it was getting poor reviews, mostly on the grounds of being derivative of other movies. After finally seeing it I'm perplexed by those accusations. I agree it's derivative, but no more than any other sci-fi film as of recent. Basically movie hipsters colluded together for some unknown reason to quash this movie, probably because it's cool to hate Tom Cruise. Their accusations are paradoxical anyway because the films they accuse Oblivion of being derivative of are themselves derivative of other movies.

It's a great film. It's nothing super profound or thought provoking. It has some plot holes, and it is derivative of other sci-fi films (like movie hipsters' favorite slideshow "La Jetee"). However it's got fine acting, an entertaining plot, and fantastic special effects. I hate CGI but this film blends CGI seamlessly with practical effects. So anyway, watch this movie.

Spaceballs, a sci-fi comedy, has nothing on this masterpiece. I could not stop laughing when the drones appeared, who came up with this visual, let alone the R2D2 sounds? The super high tech TeT Commander can't even get a decent transmission and was always on the 'fritz. I loved Melissa Leo, what a departure from her typical Southern sweetness, oh wait...

Tommy had me at "Risky Business" and his performance fell just as flat. Apologies, I know how hard you work at your craft. Maybe when you are 60 we can get a little more lateral motion.

Olga HotBabe is stunning with so many head shots of her emoting, er sleeping, and were beautiful. I am guessing she is the new Angelina, but no comparison on the acting level, she just seemed scared and uncomfortable during the film. Can hardly blame her sidling up to the Big Boys.

The scene that provided the highest entertainment value was the Scav Torture Chamber. Now, when you are desperate for a drone flyer and there is only ONE, what do you do? You smash him to bits, tie him up, flame the Draqnet bright lights on him and recite poetry, gots to end on a polite note. My friends, it doesn't get any better than this.

Enjoyed the Zep tune on the grassy knoll, and other musical inputs. However, the sound was so disjointed, i.e. dialog barely a whisper, action scenes cranked up 1000%, constantly had to adjust the volume, unclear if that was an editing problem.

I guess the crowning achievement is that our man hooks up with two major hotties, take that Katy!  Recommend for pure comedy, especially if you are a big sci-fi fan.

You know, this is one time where a director can make or break a film.  Granted the material is nonsense to work with but the pacing is painful.  There are only so many plane takeoffs and landings that one can bear.
The plot, if there is one, is about alien invasion and how they devastated the landscape.  (You know, a species that can take down the moon -- which makes no sense either as the gravitational forces would put the moon back together rather quickly) should have no problem inserting a retro virus into the atmosphere and taking down all life on earth.
On top of that there are many planets and moons in our solar system that have huge bodies of water that don't require so much work.  Europa, a moon on Jupiter comes to mind but Mars has water, so does our own moon and so does Mercury and you don't have to fight off the indigenous population.
Finally, what was the point of the film in the first place?

2013 brought in a sizable influx of science fiction movies, with many of them being quite good. This was the year of films like Gravity, Hunger Games: Catching Fire, World War Z, Elysium, Iron Man 3, Pacific Rim, Ender's Game, Riddick, Star Trek: Into Darkness and several more. Quite a haul for sci-fi fans. Oblivion was part of this pack, and conceptually it did stand out. The movie is visually stunning with some creative slants on the post apocalyptic sci-fi genre. However it does lack at extra magic you get from a truly great film. Still even with this limitation it is a very worthwhile experience.

The plot starts off in 2077, 60 years after an alien attack cracked the moon like an egg (and subsequently sent Earth into climate chaos). Jack Harper (Tom Cruise) is a technician assigned to fix and maintain robotic drones used to protect massive fusion generators powering a massive spaceship set to take the surviving humans to a colony on Titan. Harper is told there are still aliens, called Scavs (or scavengers), that wish to sabotage their exodus. This is how the story starts, but it really moves into new territory from there.

One of the bigger problems this movie had was how it was promoted. A lot of spoiler info that was better left for the audience to experience on their own was practically given away on the promotional trailers for the film. This is a serious lapse in judgment, as it significantly lowered the impact of one of the biggest plot twists in the film. Thus undermining the main draw to watch it. Granted there are other plot twists that thankfully Universal didn't give away, but I believe the damage was done. It may very well have had a hand in reducing ticket sales. I usually avoid as much as I can putting any spoilers on a review, and in spite of the boondoggle already burdened on this film I will still do my best not to ruin this film for you.

Oblivion is based on a conceptual story created by Arvid Nelson and director Joseph Kosinski that was planned to be a graphic novel, but never was made. The story back then was already intended to be feature film, so all the work done for the never-published comic was used to pitch the film. The story itself got a lot of people excited from pre-production onward, and I can see why. There is this mix of environments with Jack living in a sterile and modern environment that affords lavish comforts and high technology, and then you have the fallen Earth (Manhattan to be precise) that looks so barren and alien with a few instances of the old city jutting up from the dirt or entombed in it. The story gives you a run of the mill day for Jack (a great exposition device for establishing the setting) and then slowly unravels what you think is going on into something quite the opposite. When left to its own devices this is some really good storytelling.

The real gem of this film is the imagery. The aforementioned "fallen Earth" is quite a site to see. Imagine Manhattan swallowed up in what seems like centuries of soil piling on top. The flyby scenes where you get an expansive view of the surroundings are gorgeous. The lighting and time of day give a wonderfully soft overcast, making it all look that much more deserted. All the high tech stuff looks really sleek as well as functional. From Jacks Bubble Ship to his high rise (I mean really high) dwellings all show some innovation in design that you only see in conceptual drawings, but hardly ever come up in a live action film. Weapons are cool looking. The drones are very cool looking (even if they have a convenient Achilles heel). Being a fan of sci-fi tech I really appreciate the attention to detail. All in all there isn't a single scene in this film that doesn't deserve some amount of praise for how well it was presented.

The problems start after the plot twists have been established and you are left with what to do about it all. That's where the movie loses much of the wonder it was establishing in lieu of moving the plot forward. I can't help but think more thought should have been put into the third act as it feels like a different movie. Where the previous acts were fascinating and had an air of mystery now we fall into common trappings seen on many other sci-fi movies. It's not necessarily bad, and it doesn't ruin the film for me. It just doesn't measure up to the potential of what could have been.

There are reviewers who have pointed out several "plot holes"  in Oblivion, but I would like to set the record straight. A lot of these plot holes are more about the viewer's short sightedness on what's going on than actual limitations on the writing and directing. Suffice it to say there is more to finding a "hole" than just calling out something that doesn't make sense. You have to expand your line of thinking beyond why you don't think it makes sense and look for reasons how they can. I can't go into details, as doing so would bring out spoilers, but lets just say this movie is nowhere near the swiss cheese of logic many make it out to be.

This is the best release to date as far as viewing options are concerned. You get the Blu-Ray, the DVD and codes for a digital download. Visually the blu-ray is reference level material. It looks absolutely perfect in 1080p MPEG-4 AVC format. It helps that the movie was filmed in 4K mastered in 2K resolution. The audio is English DTS-HD Master Audio 7.1 and sounds about as good as it looks. There is also Spanish and French dubs at DTS 5.1 (subtitles too). The extras are funny in that the packaging is misleading on how much is in there, but what little you get is actually the benchmark for what a good listing of extras should have. Here is the breakdown:

Promise of a New World: The Making of Oblivion - This is a 48 minute documentary that is broken into five parts. Destiny talks about the on location shots, physical sets and story development. Voyage is all about that cool bubble ship in the movie. Combat is on the stunts and action scenes. Illusion is the visual and computer generated image effects. Harmony is about the music score. All of these sections combine to make a pretty comprehensive behind the scenes look at the movie with very little promotional fluff.

Commentary - Both director/writer Joseph Kosinski and Tom Cruise provide the commentary. While the movie was Kosinski's baby Cruise had a fair amount of input in conceptual design. The two kind of lay on thick the praise they have for Oblivion, but I suppose you can't blame then as you can tell this was a labor of love. In spite of those distractions the commentary is actually quite informative and makes for a fascinating view into how the movie was made.

Deleted Scenes - These are four very short scenes, but man are they good. "Bubbleship Flyby" is less than a minute but it's a great view of the flying vehicle and shows a little extra something you didn't know about the platform they live on. "Stadium: The Original Opening" is a minute and a half and is a must as it explains a little bit about the drone's weak spot. "Medkit" is also around a minute and a half and expands slightly the medical technology on Oblivion and is kind of a decent character development scene. "The Archives" is less than a minute and has a tiny bit of character development. Some I can see where taken out due to redundancy (medkit was seen in a later scene and such), but it's a shame some interesting details were left out of the movie.

M83 Isolated Score - You get the full film score in uncompressed 24bit/96kHz Dolby TrueHD 5.1 for your listening pleasure.

Digital Copy via Ultraviolet  - Great to have it, but it's another one of those stupid offers that has an expiration date on it. If you wait too long to get this disk you may not be able to get the digital copy. Why the dummies stick with this kind of restriction is beyond my understanding. They are pretty much pushing you to download a torrent or some other download with this kind of attitude.

Oblivion is a worthwhile movie with lots of great things to see and experience. It's a good movie, but not a great one. Good enough to say if you are a science fiction fan this should be required viewing. If you are Tom Cruise fan I would say this is also required for you as well. Popcorn movie fans I think will also find something to enjoy here as well. If you can get by on the limitations discussed you are in for a treat.

Poor Tom has to maintain things on worn-out Earth(such as the guardian globes) by himself, oblivious to what really lives there(he thinks he's being threatened) and what is really going on with the "people" telling him what to do.  Conflict ensues when he starts to put things together and tries to resolve the problem.
Very clever reveal at the end! I didn't see it coming!

Often I feel like people expect too much from a movie, like every new thing is supposed to completely blow you away or otherwise its not worth anything, which absolutely is not true. While not the most incredible thing ever like some people think it was supposed to be, Oblivion was a solid sci-fi movie throughout. I'm not going to try to argue with the naysayers because that pretty hard, all I am going to say is that I personally enjoyed it. It gave me a sense of nostalgia in that it has some sort of indistinct feeling that I've sorta seen it before, and I don't mean that in a bad way, I mean it in a good way. It felt like a classic old sci-fi movie, nothing specific really, just kind of that "feeling", ya know? Well thats my maybe more than two bits, but that's what I have to say.

This movie moves along at a quick pace and when Jack Harper rescues an unknown woman who crashed on Earth his world begins to unravel. This movie was interesting and entertaining.

Oblivion is a science fiction film about Jack Harper,one of the last mechanics remaining on earth that on a spectacular future Earth that has evolved beyond recognition. His confrontation with the past will lead him on a journey of redemption and discovery as he battles to save mankind. This movie boast of an intriguing central mystery and strong performances from Tom Cruise and Morgan Freeman as well as great production values. Unfortunately,it was thinly scripted and it suffers a lot from it. Its themes about self-sacrifice,heroism and humanity are somewhat lacking. It could have been a great film but the screenplay made it just an average for the viewer.

You must watch this movie a half a dozen times to really keep getting more and more out of it.  It is not as it seems on the surface.  My husband loves it so much now, but didn't get it in the beginning.  He now spouts, "Are we an Effective Team?"  all the time.... Good stuff.

Epic style movie futuristic movie with an interesting plot twist. Most interestingly, this movie's plot demonstrates an age old propaganda technique - the construction of a false narrative or "big lie" out of the careful, channeled reassembly of reality - motivating people to unknowingly work against their own interests. The main character's mind, even after a mandatory memory wipe, is still troubled with the most forbidden questions of propaganda - the WHY. Something that we all should not be "oblivious" to these days.

Then Cruise #2 chokes out #1 and the choke lasts a very long time, long enuf to get tied up with a towel and lay in the dirt still comatose.  Hint, in a 'choke out' the loser either dies or wakes up in a minute after.
