My first watch was in theaters, and it was awesome! It really gave the sense that earth had come to an end and only bits and pieces were left, like some of the landmarks shown in New York. I bought this movie from amazon and have watched it again. Knowing the end of the movie, it was very cool to try to catch things i missed seeing it for the first time. Action sequences were top notch, and Cruise and Kurylenko make it easy to invest in their characters. WORTH THE BUY!

If you're looking for an okay sci-fi post-apocalyptic movie to watch, you could do worse than Oblivion. You could do a lot better too. It's the future and astronaut Jack Harper (Cruise) is running around doing work fixing machines on a destroyed planet Earth. Earth is all messed up because aliens blew up the moon 60 years ago. The movie has some great visuals and, while there is a lot of predictability, there's enough to keep you guessing and engaged in the movie. They did a good job keeping it only 2 hours long. No need to stretch it out, just present a good popcorn flick.

The only things that really bugged me about Oblivion were the Matrix rip-offs. Yes, a man vs. machine sci-fi film is going to draw those comparisons, but the droids in Oblivion are ridiculously similar to the sentinels in The Matrix, and I expected to see Neo show up in one of the final scenes of the movie ("Whoa!").

In a lot of ways Oblivion also reminded me of the movie "Moon" with Sam Rockwell. Kind of ironic that they blew up the moon in this and the entire story of THAT film takes place on the moon. "Moon" is FAR superior to Oblivion. Less action and CGI, more suspense and drama. If you liked Oblivion, you'll love Moon. If you didn't like Oblivion or only thought it was so-so, you'll enjoy Moon more. And you won't leave that one thinking you've just seen an elaborate Verison "Droid" commercial!

I braced myself at first thinking this would another Cruise movie, but was pleasantly surprised! Many reviewers have stated the plot is a repeat of many other sci-fi movies, but this films delivery is what makes it so enjoyable and that alone deserves kudos! The cinematography is beautiful and offers many details for the eyes, pair this with the movies soundtrack and you get a wonderfully complimented pair that adds new twists from start to finish. The cast is excellent
So, we follow Cruise onto future Earth, as all humans have left for a safer planet while he and his stand-in wife Riseborough work together to patrol the Earths resources and protect their mining sites. The story now begins with an inquisitive Cruise who presses to uncover the war, the Earths resources, the truth behind a mysterious crash site and the cause of his dreams, who the Scavs really are and how he can start over.
Overall, I highly recommend watching this flick to the science fiction fans.

A rare work that included a story, great action and a really good special effects.  This kept my family guessing and everyone was glad we watched it.

For one thing, the art direction is superb, and the special effects to die for. That's why there's 3 stars. Unfortunately, this is basically a variation of the plot of Battlefield Earth morphed with Independence Day, Battlefied Earth was one of the worst plots ever, so please hollywood, stop remaking that.

Oblivion does a much better job with the plot, but the flaws that existed in Battlefield Earth still exist here.. in that once you make the aliens so superior, the possibilities of actually winning literally hard to believe.

The first half or 2/3 is very watchable, visually stunning. Rent it for that alone. But there is a demarcation line (and you'll know when it happens) when the movie changes from a contemplative SCIFI story into a cheap video game mentality. It's like there were two different directors.

But like I said, I'd watch it, and shut it off once it hits that line, because you'll just be sorry.

Everything that I heard about this movie had me believing that it would not be very good. I was pleasantly surprised with the story. Morgan Freeman was of course excellent but was used in a very limited role. I didn't care for the actress in this story and the conclusion left something to be desired but I didn't mind it as much as some others.

I like scifi as much as the next guy, probably more, but there's nothing new here.  It's a clean and professional production of a decent script, and far far better than Prometheus, not as good a story as Minority Report.  Of course Morgan Freeman makes everything better.  I'm waiting for the movie that stars only Morgan and Michael Caine.

For sure the plot had some holes in it and,  like a lot of movies,  this one borrowed from other successful predecessors.  In the end though, Oblivion does what movies are supposed to do and that is entertain us for a few hours and possibly make us think about how some of the movies' themes parallel our own lives. Excellent casting, so-so directing,  but visually stunning and beautiful, Oblivion is a great way to get out of your weekly routine and treat your imagination to some above average sci-fi fun.

The movie production and storyline can be judged on it's own merits, but the disk set was all there and performed flawlessly.

The movie had me in its grip in moments. The home they lived in was very Sci-Fi-like.  Initially, I thought his partner was a hologram.  I guess they wanted me to think that.  I really enjoyed the scenes with Cruise flying as well as the scenes into the earth's openings, in the stadium, and of course at the lake.  Each scene was done so well and made the story line fluid.  I believed.  At just the point when I was wondering what was happening, things started kickin' ! The plot was much more intriguing than I thought earlier in the show.  It's complications were unsettling and made for a terrific and powerful movie.  The characters were all stellar :) the FX were truly inspiring, and the story was compelling.  I have watched it four times and will enjoy it again and again.  We have a TV room and had a group of our Sci-Fi friends over and they also found "Oblivion" TOP-NOTCH ! !

Despite what some reviewers have said about "Oblivion" that it reminds them of other science fiction films, this is surely a keeper in my collection of great science fiction movies. Most of the "reminders" of other films the reviewers pointed out, can be found in any science fiction from almost any year. I won't go into detail, because I think the claims are unwarranted criticisms of "Oblivion". Some of the films critics said it "copied" from were films that were written after "Oblivion". The original treatment for the film was written by the director, Joseph Kosinski, in 2007. Nonetheless, all science fiction films "borrow" from multiple sources. Most likely from science itself. I cannot recall the exact details of what was "borrowed", but I do remember that they were pretty common traits of many science fiction stories. Either way, if you enjoyed "Oblivion" as much as I did, I think keeping it around is a great idea. I've installed it on my iPad so I can watch it any time.

Memorable film.

When Tron 2 Screenwriter, Joseph Kosinski, started shopping for a Publisher for his graphic novel, Oblivion, they told him it was so good that he should bring it right to the big screen. Before you know it, some big names signed out and the film was released as a big budget blockbuster. There are a ton of cool gadgets in a story about a futuristic world, that has been destroyed by war. What initially turned me on to this film was the trailer, which show you the technology, but tell you almost nothing about the story. The films description is the same way, it tells you very little and really gets your curiosity going. The story starts by telling us what has become of the world, 65 years in the future. The planet has been destroyed by war and the humans have left the planet for one of Saturn's moons. All that's left is a bunch of technology meant to harvest Earth's resources for the people on Titan. The remaining rebels mean to sabotage this technology and it's the job of Jack and Vicka to repair and protect the technology from the last remaining terrorists. Tom Cruise stars and by now we all know how I feel about Tom Cruise. Fortunatly for Mr. Kosinski, this was a film that Cruise was really into and he does give one of his strongest performance since Minority Report. Cruise is terrific and is the main reason this film works in the beginning. With the extensive back story, it takes a while for anything substantive to happen and that's where Cruise and the unique technology come into play. They carry the film from the shocking beginning into the heart of the story. Once this film gets going it is one of the best pure Science Fiction films to come along in years. To his credit, even though the film is weird and starts out slow, Kosinski wouldn't let Hollywood touch it. The result is an old school type of Science Fiction film, done with modern technology. The geeks will love this movie, but there is also enough of a side stories and some amazing special effects that will help gain the majority of audiences. Oblivion was a terrific ride and something you don't see everyday, I really can't recommend it enough.

While Oblivion was an entertaining movie, it raised far too many questions that it casually sidestepped. I sincerely hope that there is a follow-up so that we can experience more of the universe that Oblivion introduced. I feel that it has great potential as a continued storyline.
If you like Tom Cruise and you like action movies, then you will probably enjoy this movie.  I know we did.
This movie doesn't let you look away. It's full of action and we really enjoyed it as we do move of Freeman's and Cruise's movies.  Well worth the buy.

2013 was a great year to be a science fiction movie fan. More than 10 sci fi films were released, all with great potential to be be top-notch.

To be 100% honest, I didn't have high hopes for Oblivion if only because the other films looked so strong by comparison. Oblivion exceeded my expectations and then some.

I won't go into the storyline as many other reviewers already have. I will say that yes, certain elements are derivitive. There are parts of Independence Day, The Matrix and other (rather good btw) sci fi stories in the plot of Oblivion. However, at no point did I feel that any other film was being "ripped-off". Oblivion has enough of it's own original ideas and variation of classic themes to make it stand on it's own. New and old ideas both come together and make a rather satisfying film.

Tom Cruise is solid here as is Morgan Freeman (is he ever in a bad movie?). The rest of the cast - especially Andrea Riseborough - are both believable and relatable. I especially enjoyed Melissa Leo as "Sally". Definitely an interesting take on the character she portrays.

Lastly, both the special effects and score were great - both added quite a lot to the film.

I've watched it numerous times and highly recommend it.

I enjoy well done sci-fi and this was definitely well done. I'm not sure why the Hollywood critics were so negative on the movie. It may have been obvious who the actual bad/good guys were without too much insight but,it was still extremely well done. I can't stand Tom Cruise but,he still delivered a great performance. Isn't that why we watch actors,to actually be entertained?I watched it three times so I could figure out some of the blurry areas of why,when and where. Part of that is due to our lack of a decent sound system and the other was that I just enjoyed it. My wife went out and bought the dvd for a Christmas present. She liked the love story aspect as well. I give it two thumbs up.

Tom cruise can put forth a good performance , he's not a great actor but he's a very good one , when scientology doesn't get in the way of his brains functioning. That cult can make people into robots. Here he overcomes the brainwashing to put in a very good performance. He has to carry the film basically and he deserves a lot of credit for it. this movie is a complicated film , that is extremely well done. In fact , it's one of the better sci fi films that I have seen in a while. Something that the great tv show 'the outer limits' would have done , without any big effects though. And this is spectacular in the special effects realm. It would have been better in 3d though.  I will say that if someone in a review tells you the plot of this movie , then  avoid it. other than if they say " aliens destroyed the earth and tom is stopping the scaves"  then you will not know what is happening!  And that is the best way to watch this top notch sci fi film. The rest of the cast other than the other tech ,  are in very small parts. Morgan freedman and a few others have small parts but they do a good job. This is movie that you can't just half watch , you have to watch it and learn , what's happening as it goes along. It has a surprise in store for you.  I can't imagine any sci fi fan not enjoying this movie. The effects are so stunning and the story is excellent. Even 20 years ago this type of movie would have been impossible to film  properly.  It's taking place in 60 years but the tech does work , WHEN you see the ending. Till then I was like???? how did mankind get this advanced.  SO watch this and find out!  the blu ray is stunning!  More recent movies always look fantastic on blu!  And this one especially so. There are four deleted scenes that should have been put back in to the film. as they were very short and one of them 'the archive' is important to the story.  this is worth watching. It's a nA movie of the highest caliber.

I kept wanting this to be a mashup of Shawshank Redemption, Top Gun, the video game Portal, and E.T. And then I saw it and it WAS exactly what I wished for but I realized I was completely outside of my mind. This sci-fi apocalyptic thriller had depicted humanity imprisoned to another planet, the protagonist Tom Cruise is a top gun astronaut that's blindly performing chores for round robots that continuously monitor ocean consuming machines for so called fusion energy that we are led to believe will be used on the planet that humanity now lives on. Sprinkle in a twist and Hollywood seems to think it'll be a blockbuster hit??? Ugh. There's really only one twist, and is it ever so cliche. Stick to the classics I mentioned above. Just like the title, I rented this because I was bored and there was nothing else to rent.  I actually liked the whole thing.

I originally saw this at the IMAX theater at the space needle in Seattle ... huge screen.  Between the screen size and the extreme panoramic filming, you almost felt like you were truly flying, falling, and driving in many of the scenes.  Also, the movie was fantastic.  Since then, I have bought the movie and have watched at home.  While it is not quite the same experience as in the IMAX theater, the videography is amazing and the sets are beautiful.

I expected a little more from this duo of Tom and Morgan.  They did an admirable job though, given the emotionless narrative of this futuristic story.  There just wasn't enough meat on this hog.

The quality of the image and sound were very good though.  A blue tinted world, cold and foreboding, but still managed to eek out enough flesh tones for our benefit.  The sound was impressive, although again, it was lacking much emotion.

Here's my big issue though...  Who came up with the original score?  It was worse than elevator music in a retirement home.  Harsh, brassy, and juvenile.  I mentioned an emotionless story?  Well, you got an emotionless series of background tracks too, baby!  Sympatico with our story here.

There was potential though.  Some moments of untapped human drama.  Some doors left unopened.  In a way, this film serves as a reminder that you should run with tears, if tears make a story better.  You should build sympathetic characters, worthy of our care.

In spite of featuring Tom Cruise (I can think of better actors for the starring role in this one), this movie is really entertaining.  Plot is very good, it unfolds itself at the right pace and it has a couple of very interesting twists, although at some point I guess I figured it out part of it (maybe because I had watched "Moon" not so long ago  --oops!).  Enjoyable, recommendable.

I normally enjoy Tom Cruise's movies a little. This movie for me moved my mind into a capsule of fantasy that was kind of like a bland dry saltine cracker. It starts off with a essence calming sterile fantasy...with its simplistic tone driving the romanticism. Watching it was like skipping pages in a book to blank ones then back to half a page then to a whole one...very choppy and cheap to me in a mild way. I kept on waiting for Jodie Foster to show up (Elysium)....ha ha. Anywho....I also wish they would have chosen another actress for Tom Cruise's lost wife (Olga Kurylenko). The actress they chose for the role...her heavy accent and whispery volume/voice made me want to stop watching. If the movie overall had been a stronger one with more action...then the light and airy presence Olga brought wouldn't have been so annoying. I appreciate the attempt for this movie made for something more blank canvas artistically, but it just didn't intrigue me enough to CARE.

This movie was a pleasant surprise. I went in with little to no expectations and was captivated for the duration of the movie. It is not a short movie as it runs for 124 minutes. For a new director/writer's first outing, I have to say I am impressed. This movie has very strong visuals and the set designs are just remarkable. The story is rather simple but it was well crafted, directed and acted. Sometimes, it is how the story is told that makes up for the simplistic story and here in succeeds. The soundtrack is another pleasant surprise as it fits the movie to a tee.

I hope to see more projects from Joseph Kosinski (the director and writer) as this is indeed a most promising start.

If you like sci-fi, you'll like this movie. The soundtrack is worth a view if nothing else! It was shot in Iceland (I believe) and is piled full of gorgeous scenery. It's also a cool story and well executed.
This is an excellent movie.  This product was delivered on time and was exactly what I expected.  It is a wonderful product and I recommend it.
Oblivion was a good movie.  I like Tom Cruise, but I am not a huge fan of his in particular.  But Oblivion had me sucked in, for most of the movie.  I would recommend this movie to just about anyone

This is a review of the Blu-ray disc itself, not the movie. I enjoyed the movie enough to buy it after renting it on a previous occasion. Not sure what the issue is because I experienced the same exact problem from a rented Blu-ray version of this movie. I ended up bringing the Blu-ray back to the rental store to trade for the regular DVD version.

I load the movie into my Sony Blu-ray player, it spins, it does it's Blu-ray internet loading thing, it plays the Universal logo video clip, does more internet loading, then it just sit's there!!! I can't play it, I can't skip to the next chapter, I can't fast-forward, I can't navigate to the movie's main menu, I can't do anything except eject the stupid disc!!!!!!!!!!

The same exact thing happened with the Blu-ray rental disc. It simply won't play no matter what I do!!! I hope I can get my money back from BestBuy.  :(

*** Follow up ***

As it turns out, a great many other people are having the same problem with this and other Blu-ray disc titles. Apparently, the fix is to disconnect your Blu-ray player's internet connection. After doing that, it should play fine. It worked! Now my disc plays as it should. WTF????

From a technical aspect, this movie is stunning, from the visuals, sounds, and score (great score by M83).  I have to give kudos to the sound engineers for making the vocal distinct, from low to high levels of sound.  I hate movies that blast you with volume while vocals are low and hard to hear.

The bluray version of this movie will definitely showcase a good home theater setup.

The only ding, and a disappointing ding for me (and hence the lack of a 5 star technical review), is that the True Dolby HD isolated score is staticy and drops out on my setup.  Searching around, it appears I am not the only person that has experienced this problem.  I have a Sony S790 BD player with dual HDMI output (one to my receiver and one to my TV).  It is possible the problem is not disc related, but have not had the time to do more experimentation.

As for the movie itself, I was pleasantly surprised that I enjoyed, and liked it more after a repeat viewing.  Repeated viewings give you better appeciation of the technical aspects of the movie along with character reactions (especially Julia, played by Olga Kurylenko) in certain scenes.  Although Tom Cruise does his best in real-life to make you hate him personally, he does an acceptable acting job.

The movie does have some predictability in the plot and shades of other past sci-fi movies, but not everything is explicitly explained (especially the motives of the alien), requiring the viewer to figure things out on their own (which I like).  If you are a serious sci-fi fan, and if you take some time to readup on some of the insights of the film makers, you may gain a greater appreciation of the movie.
saw the movie at the theaters in imax. got here quick. wasent as good as the big screen but still love the movie.

My wife has always been a Tom Cruise fan, so when this came out I got it for her. As for me, Mr. Cruise does a fine job in the movies that he does, but I feel that he is miss cast for some (War of the Worlds).

Oblivion is an entertaining film, with excellent visuals, a finely crafted setting, and strong lead character. Tom Cruise does an excellent job as Jack Harper, nailing both action and emotional scenes. The action is a treat, though the climactic shootout is a bit clumsy.

If sci-fi tech is a draw for you, there is plenty of drool-inspiring technology in this film - cool ships, cool weapons, the greatest AI drone sound effects ever created, and computer GUIs that can only be described as arousing.

There were a few aspects to the story that seemed unbelievable, but actual got explained later on. The plot pulled a few surprises, which was a treat as I went into this expecting a very straightforward story.

I knocked off a star because some of the supporting characters (particularly Morgan Freeman) were underwhelming, and the end was too cheesy. Despite these misgivings, I'd recommend it overall if you're a sci-fi junkie.

If I could rate the special effects separately from the acting, I'd give 5 stars to the effect and 2 stars to the acting.  The movie itself is a banquet of sweeping, breathtaking scenes and effects.  It is well enough achieved to allow the viewer to accept these stunning images as real and become immersed in the picture.  Sadly, though, Tom Cruise - who is capable of some pretty fine acting - is just Tom Cruise.  He's wooden and predictable.  Even Morgan Freeman somehow felt like he was just being himself.  There was nothing unique or identifiable about the characters.  It really took away from the movie which at first had me believing I might see more by the end.

ON the good side: great pictures, breathtaking shots and scenes in the atmosphere an on the "ruined" Earth as well. Well done.
The problem is that these are kind of standard now, so acting and story still, or even more make a difference. After 10-15 minutes, when you get used the style (unexpected camera-angle changes and openings) and you start focusing on the story, you start to develop a sense of emptiness. Which not because of the hopeless future of Earth, as the movie suggests it, but because the story is very shallow. Without ruining the story for those who haven't seen it yet, don't expect anything unexpected, or smart. (Note: I am not a Cruise fan: ) Also, I think Cruise has been stuck on the sad no-man's land between the charming boy and the wise man (he may never get there). I don't think that showing his butts and his (okay for a man in his fifties) chest is enough to make a good movie.
Okay if you are tired and just want to relax and make your visual-mind-center work, but you are better of not watching it if you into sci-fi and like the intellectual part of movies.

Oblivion(released April/13)stars,among others,Tom Cruise,Olga Kurylenko,Andrea Riseborough,Morgan Freeman and Nikolaj Coster-Waldau. Oblivion is certainly a different film,and Cruise is back doing what he does best;playing the intense,somber but conflicted role we know him to o so well. While he and co stars have a lot to say and do,the ultra long story has just far too much to tell,as it jumps from one narrative to another and back again. It unfortunately drags the film down and us with it.
Speaking of which,we find ourselves in the year 2070. Earth is in total shambles and our hero is living high above the Earth with his female counterpart. They are singly manning the maintenance and security of the planet after its devastation involving a global conflict with aliens some 60 years before. There are gigantic water sucking machines that provide needed energy for the Earth colony on the moon of Titan,the largest of Saturn's moons. To aid the pair in their tasks are drones,round flying machines that help the pair cover the long distances involved in their jobs. They are monitored constantly from the "Tet",a gigantic space ship,which is the transition platform for those heading from Earth to Titan. In fact Cruise and his colleague are due to leave their posts in two weeks,barring any complications.
Cruise has been bombarded for ages by memories of a woman he met on top of the Empire State building. One day they pick up a transmission coming from the top of that same building;the rest of which is buried deep beneath in the ground. He investigates to find out it has been deliberately programmed for transmission into space and for coordinates in a zone on Earth where there is no known life to speak of. Cruise cuts the signal,but shortly there after a space craft falls from the sky. Upon his arrival at the crash site he manages to rescue a woman from a stasis tube. A drone,also dispatched to the area from the Tet,kills the remaining survivors,much to his chagrin. The woman,as it turns out,is the self same one from Cruise's dreams.
Cruise returns the tube to his habitat high above the Earth. They bring the woman back to life and interrogate her as best they can. Her main concern is getting the flight recorder from her crashed ship. Reluctantly Cruise takes her planet side and both get taken prisoners by Scavengers,or Scavs for short. It is these people that Cruise has been told were of alien origin and the ones that still sabotage their equipment. The Scavs however have a different story to tell. They are not of alien origin but human,and have been fighting the real aliens for years;the ones from the Tet who invaded Earth originally. They(the Scavs)want to send a destructive device into the Tet and blow it up,but they need Cruise to program a drone for them. When he refuses they send him and the woman he revived back into the wilderness to find answers in a radiation zone no one has been able to enter. Along the way the two stop at the Empire State Building again where the woman rekindles his memories further,only to find she is his wife. Cruise's partner has sent his ship back down to him and sees the two in an embrace. When Cruise returns to the habitat she refuses his entry and reports him to their superiors. This has the effect of unleashing a special drone underneath the habitat which first kills Cruise's colleague then turns on him. He is saved by his wife.
The two flee but get pursued by three drones. Cruise manages to eliminate the three but not before he crash lands in the so called radiation zone. There his wife gets seriously wounded and  he finds out there are more caretakers like himself. In fact he witnesses one land and perform maintenance on a drone. It is in fact a clone of himself. While Cruise's official number is 49,this one's is 52. Cruise kills the clone,returns to the clone's habitat#52,greets his former colleague(obviously a clone also),and returns to Earth with a med kit to help save his wife's life. Armed with this new knowledge Cruise and his wife return to the Scavs and agree to help them defeat the aliens. Before they can get a programmed drone up and fling with the installed nuclear device,they are attacked by three more clones. Many people are killed,and its leader seriously wounded. The only option now is to take the bomb up to the Tet personally. Cruise puts his wife back into the stasis tube and blasts off to take her back to the Tet. Along the way he listens to the flight recorder which brings back more memories from his former life. Cruise now knows it was he who led the original expedition to Titan but was side tracked to investigate the Tet. Cruise ejected the stasis tubes on board before his ship was sucked into the Tet. The aliens then cloned Cruise and what would become his female colleague. The aliens sent thousands of Cruises to Earth to destroy the human population and left a few behind to tend to the planet destroying water devices.
Cruise manages to enter the heart of the Tet. When he opens the stasis tube it is the leader of the Scavs. Both Cruise and he detonate the bomb together destroying the aliens. Fast forward two years and Cruises wife and their daughter are now living in a remote cabin on Earth Cruise had built prior to his death. Out of some brush across a lake arrives some Scavs and Cruise,but the numbered 52 clone,the one we thought Cruise had killed. It seems his memories had been awakened by Cruise#49 and his wife's presence and he had been searching for her ever since.
There is much more to this plot,but as you can tell,it is long and very involved and we are taken back and forth,from one story to a back story,and back again and on and on. There are certainly some head scratching moments as when we get fooled by Freeman's presence in the Tet,and clone#52's appearance at the end as he"reunites" with his wife. Also when we view the back story and see Cruise eject the stasis tubes from his ship which is getting sucked into the Tet,we must ask:why wasn't the ejected section also sucked into the ship?Cruise has tried everything in his power to get out of the TET's grip and failed,but an ejecting part of the ship miraculously could break away of its own power? Hmmm. And there is also the question of clones,as in how many more were out there with latent memories of Cruises wife and when they came searching what would they do when they found their wife? Hmmmm. Questions,questions and more questions,with no answers. Or should I say a lot of plot holes that are quite deep?You decide.

OBLIVION, starring Tom Cruise, is a science fiction movie, taking place on the planet Earth in the year 2077.  Tom Cruise plays a low-level employee. His job is to scout the surface of the planet Earth, and detect residual alien invaders who hide out in various parts of the landscape on the planet earth, and kill them.  The alien invaders are called, "Scavengers."  These Scavengers had destroyed the moon.  This effect was copied from TIME MACHINE, starring Guy Pierce.  Any person, having seen TIME MACHINE, will be startled by the shameless copying of the image of the broken-up moon, in the sky.  If you did a side-by-side comparison of the images of the broken-up moon, it would be apparent to you that this aspect of the  movie, OBLIVION, was copied from TIME MACHINE.  Also, the Scavengers had caused earthquakes and tsunamis, as part of their invasion of earth.  Tom Cruise, and co-workers, do their job from tetrahedral space stations that hover 3,000 feet above the ground.  These hovering tetrahedrons are inspiring to look at, and resemble the floating world in GULLIVER'S TRAVELS, starring Ted Danson.  The other characters working on the tetrahedral station (Tower 49) are Victoria "Vika" Olsen, who also is a love interest, and  a supervisor, named, "Sally."  "Sally," is seen only on a television screen.  Sally has an anonymous persona.  She utters ominous platitudes, such as, "Are you working together as an effective team?"  Sally's character is like that of BIG BROTHER in the story, 1984.  Sally's image on the television screen is distorted by static.  This effect was copied from the original STAR WARS movies, where the hologram of Princes Leah was intentionally distorted by electronic static.  In this way, OBLIVION is derivative of STAR WARS.

When Tom Cruise encounters the Scavengers during the course of his routine hunting expeditions to kill the Scavengers, what is disclosed is that the Scavengers have voice-altering devices that cause their voices to have a non-human timbre.  This effect was also copied from STAR WARS.  During Tom Cruise's many trips to the surface of Earth, he frequently encountered half-buried, or substantially buried, artifacts from New York City.  These include buried versions of STATUE OF LIBERTY, EMPIRE STATE BUILDING, and BROOKLYN BRIDGE.  This was copied from the film, PLANET OF THE APES, written by Rod Serling.  In PLANET OF THE APES, we see a partially buried version of STATUE OF LIBERTY.

The first 60 minutes of OBLIVION is extremely tedious.  Tom Cruise makes repeated trips to the bleak surface of Earth, hunting for Scavengers.  On occasion, he finds them.  Sometimes, they are elusive.  Tom Cruise repeatedly flies through canyons, an effect copied from the early STAR WARS movies.  Please recall the fight scenes where space vehicles speed through a canyon on the DEATH STAR.  This kind of scene is repeatedly shown on OBLIVION.  Apparently, the director, screenwriter, and producer of OBLIVION thought that Americans are too stupid to recognize all of the features from PLANET OF THE APES, TIME MACHINE (with Guy Pierce), and STAR WARS, that had been re-cycled to make OBLIVION.  Because of this, and because of the extreme tedium that is produced during the first hour of this film, I give the rating of two stars.  Eventually, it becomes apparent that OBLIVION does, in fact, contain some very clever features in its storyline, e.g., erasing memories and making replacement clones of various characters.  But these clever features cannot overcome the disappointment caused by the tedium of the first 60 minutes, and the disappointment caused by the extremely derivative nature of OBLIVION, that is, its being derivative from other sci-fi movies.

I am sorry, Mr. Cruise, I truly loved your performance in WAR OF THE WORLDS.  And I loved your rapport with Dakota Fanning in that particular film.  The storyline, the character development, and the special effects, of WAR OF THE WORLDS makes that particular film one of my all-time-favorites.  However, I am sorry to report that, relatively speaking, OBVLIVION is a dud.

A film like oblivion can sometimes remind us that there is beauty even in the austere, even in the ruin.  While I personally like the greens and the blue hues of our planet the stark black and white and brown contrasts of the post-apocalyptic "Oblivion" starring Tom Cruise, Morgan Freeman, Andrea Riseborough, and a fetching Olga Kurylenko are almost attractively fetishistic in their composition.  I suppose that the heightened tension of all those killer drones that buzz about to kill humans (timely social commentary? or sci-fi coincidence?) exacerbate how the visuals will burn themselves into the viewer's memory.

The story of a clone (whoops! spoiler) who doesn't know what he is and learns that he's doing exactly the opposite of what he thought that he was supposed to be doing is carried out well.  That Cruise's Jack Harper character becomes conflicted due to recurring images/ memories of another life is a trope that is put to good effect.  The quiet and building dissolution of his relationship with his partner/ lover/ wife (?) Victoria (a sympathetic in spite of being cold Andrea Riseborough) as he comes into closer contact with his former wife Julia (Olga Kurylenko) plays out in subtle dramatic fashion and surprisingly makes this cold post-apocalypse feel warmer.  Freeman's (always a solid choice to get him into your movie) freedom fighter Beech is really only there to act as the cipher to Cruise's Harper who holds the key to someone's oblivion.

A solid sci-fi actioner.  Must have been pretty amazing in 3-D on the big screen but it does translate nicely to our tellies at home.
