If you like Si-Fi this is a must see even if you do not like Tom Cruise.  I can't think of anything I didn't like about it.

I rented Oblivion twice. Both times, I fell asleep during the movie and during the first rental, I waited too long to resume watching before my rental period expired. So what made me rent it a second time? I thought surely the movie would get better as time went by if I had remained awake. Sadly, it didn't.
I won't review the premise of the story. There are several other reviewers who have done a much better job with that than I could ever do. What I am going to tell you, should you care to read further is that I rarely rate a review. I may rate a movie with the "star" system but I have done this only rarely. In fact, the last movie I felt compelled to express my two cents about was "Legends of the Fall" if that tells you anything. And for some reason, I find myself comparing these two movies over and over again although the stories at first glance could hardly be more alike.

Both movies have incredible cinematography whether it be showcasing real nature and it's amazing, jaw dropping beauty in "Legends of the Fall" which was filmed with such an incredible eye for detail that took your breath away as only Kevin Costner's films, "Dances with Wolves" or "Open Range" have done for me since or the talented mix of the sparse but visually compelling landscape of parts of Iceland with the special CGI effects mixed in that are showcased in this movie.

Both movies also showcase the equally gorgeous actors, Brad Pitt and Tom Cruise who in and of themselves are equally pleasing to look at if only they had exercised some of their acting skills in either movie to offer us an enjoyable movie for other reasons than just the scenery. In each movie, the main characters acted by the above mentioned artists are acted which such stoicism despite the journeys their characters take that good looks aside, it makes the movies hard to watch for any other reason other than the total visual appeal. If not for their costars in each movie there would be no redeeming acting value.

If you like CGI effects for the scenery, you will enjoy this movie. If you're looking for something to entertain you otherwise, do yourself a favor: skip this one!

I'll rent about anything with Morgan Freeman, and while I'm not a Tom Cruise fan, this movie is very good. The scenery where the film
was shot was just extraordinary. Neat storyline. I highly recommend it!

Oblivion is a great Sci Fi movie with a an actual story.  Now it is not a Popcorn Sci Fi movie.  It is a story told in a Sci Fi setting.  It is one with a good story, a story with ups and downs, but overall it weaves everything together nicely by the end.  I do feel the ending was rushed.  Considering the movie length I cannot say I am surprised.  They could have shorten some of the bits in the middle to allow for a more composed ending in the style of the movie.  It was like they had to wrap it up and the did the best that they could with the time remaining.

The acting was on point, the visuals were great.  I actually felt for the characters.  I was really interested in the universe that was being created.  That could be the reason I felt the ending was rushed.

Speaking of which I did not see the fun at the end coming, but should have.  They foreshadowed it and everything.  That how into the story that I was.
Lots of great special effects.  Not the greatest plot ever written but still fun to watch even if you're not a fan of Tom Cruise.

This movie really sucks.  The movie is way too long and by the time it really becomes a little iteresting I completely had lost interest.  Even watched it again to see if ot was better knowing the twist and it wasn't any better.  Booooo Tom Cruise.
Great story with a great supporting cast. As always, Tom Cruise over-acting diminished what could have been an otherwise great movie.

Interesting plot line, but it felt scattered. Movie opens with a lot of exposition; seemed more like the start of a video game. Just tell me the story! Not the story behind the story... But a great flick for a Friday night.
Loved it in the theater and wanted my own Blu-ray copy plus the DVD and digital copy...the triple play is a bonus and a great deal on Amazon...
Loved the premise and story line.  Effects are pretty cool too!  Morgan Freeman is always awesome.  Cruise has a solid performance.
Not a lot to say about it. It was good. It borrowed most of its ideas from other films. So there was nothing that really blew you away.
The special effects were great but the story was a mashup of many other films from the Matrix to Terminator to Mad Max.

I missed this film at the box office, but believe it didn't do well on the Big screen and with critics.
I thought it was entertaining, future oriented Sci-Fi fun.
Great concept with an unusual twist. Had me going all the way to the end. It was even ok for my toddler to watch.

At first I was getting kind of bored as the story unfolded, but once I got into it, I really loved it. The actors did a superb job and the cinematics and effects were excellent. I highly recommend it.

Where are all these writers coming from. So many good post apocalyptic, in the future type movies are hitting the screens. I liked the plot and it was pretty neat the way everything fell in place. I started to figure it out before the plot was actually revealed, but that's okay.

No movie will ever be perfect (accept Avatar and Sixth Sense). This plot and setting were both pretty interesting. I wanted a little more explanation at the end but I still give this movie a weak four stars or a good three stars. I chose four because its actually pretty clean. I notice most Crusie movies spend time on developing plots and characters vs just raw action. I like that.

This flick is one GIANT clich, with obvious, or should I say Oblivious, borrowing from past sci-fi flicks, many of them starring...TOM CRUISE!  I can always count on Tom Cruise 1.running fast 2.riding fast on a motorcycle. 3.fighting against the MAN and somehow winning in the end AND getting THE girl.

The computer in his house on the table is from Minority Report, the helicopter in the canyon fighting drones is Star Wars Episode IV, His wife injured in the desert from The English Patient, the library scenes from War of the Worlds, sand people from Star Wars IV, Tom Cruise running fast from...well, every Tom Cruise movie ever starring Tom Cruise.

Do we really need another (supposed) blockbuster film starring bigname actors such as Morgan Freeman and TOM CRUISE that succeed only in stuffing more cash in producers' and actors' pockets but leave the rest of us unwashed/moviewatchers wishing we had spent the evening shelling peas instead?

Critical reviews of Oblivion were less than strong, and trailers for it emphasized guns-n-ammo type action. While Oblivion has plenty of action and excitement, it should be classed with the "quiet" type SF film, like 2001: A Space Odyssey and Solaris, not Star Trek or Star Wars. We found this a satisfying and entertaining film, and would recommend it, despite a disappointing lack of frontal nudity.
I had a hard time following this because I was multitasking when I was watching it, but it had some nice twists on the plot.
Had a decnt story line and everything in this movie was pretty good. Tom Cruise was fantastico in the film
Very good movie, Graphics were great audio and soundtrack were amazing and a great story line with amazing screenplay, I would recomend this movie to any one! not for kids though.
This movie kept us captivated from beginning to end. Finally, a good and enjoyable sci-fi, which shows it can still be done!
Found it confusing and rambling. Probably need to watch again sometime.  I did like the creativity of the airplane etc.
It was good however you could see what was going to happen for a long time I would have liked it to be more suspenseful
The movie started out great then it took a weird turn, I don't think it was worth the money I paid.

I confess that the negative critics kept me from experiencing OBLIVION on the big screen and the mentioning of an "alien invasion" didn't exactly stimulate my appetite for Joseph Kosinski's hors d'oeuvre (IMHO, there is only one thing that alien beings might find interesting about our planet, and surprisingly the film got that right dead-on). But fortunately one of my friends insisted that I "wanted" to see the film and he was right.

Many critics claimed that OBLIVION was supposedly derivative and built on sci-fi tropes. I couldn't agree less. Joe Kosinski was never cagey about OBLIVION being an homage to the science fiction films of the 1960's and 1970's (PLANET OF THE APES and THE OMEGA MAN come to mind) and used elements and ideas from these works. But here he created something completely different, original and fresh out of these (and never at the expense of the original work like the shameless "copy and paste" of BEN HUR's chariot race in a highly anticipated movie from 1999), resulting in a film much larger than the mere sum of its parts.

On the contrary, Kosinski uses these elements and ideas as subtle hints that appearances are deceiving to tell a science fiction story in the best tradition of THE TWILIGHT ZONE, renowned for its unsuspecting story turns and twists. By the end of the film it should be abundantly obvious that the drones were neither inspired by Pacman or WALL-E but rather by a remote-controlled device in one of these films from the last century.

Admittedly, watching the film for the first time reveals what appears to be a couple of plot holes but basically these are necessary evils not to give the surprising twist away. Watching the film for the second time and from the inevitable new perspective things start to make a lot of sense and Olga Kurylenko's acting, now that audiences can fully understand what her Julia character must have gone through upon her awakening, is quite impeccable and reveals how skillful Joe Kosinski uses body language (something I had already admired in his previous film TRON: LEGACY) to tell what's going on inside his characters.

OBLIVION is presented in stunning vistas and in a cinematographic style that takes the time to tell the story without the hectic pace that often plagues contemporary movies. The Blu-ray looks fantastic, the level of detail and textures is remarkable, colors are natural and the sound design is impressive, giving the drones a unique personality and language (their "I require assistance" beacon sound will get quite a different meaning during the course of the story...).

The film is enigmatic and thrilling during the first viewing, much clearer and evident the second time, and if you still require insight there's Tom Cruise's and Joe Kosinski's inartificial audio commentary for the entire length of the film. If you buy a film on video disc for repeated viewing, experience and enjoyment, then OBLIVION is most definitely my Number One recommendation during these days.

If you're looking for fast-paced sci-fi action comic-strip-style I'd say that the latest STAR TREK reboot movie will be more to your liking. OBLIVION has plenty of good action scenes and visual eye candy (and can do without gore) but here these don't cover up the lack of an original story but rather serve to tell one that's good, thrilling and fresh. It's a passionate accomplishment I found incredibly entertaining and rewarding.
A little slow but methodical.  I enjoy the genre so it didn't bother me.  If you like sci-fi it's a good one to watch.
Typical action-packed Tom Cruise film but filled with unexpected twists & surprises.  I hate when a film is predictable.  This was VERY entertaining.  Loved it & highly recommend it.
Not a big Tom Cruise fan, but this movie was ok. They just don't make very many good movies anymore.
was a good movie to watch with a lot of what is going to happen next in it one of the movies you will want to watch again

I had no plans to follow through with this movie. Lately every movie I've been waiting to go to DVD has let me down. The previews rock my world only to find I can't sit through fifteen minutes. Grrh! Oblivion had a couple things going for it before I even pressed play. Science fiction and Tom Cruise. I live for end of the world survival drama and Tom's been one of my favorite actors since Legend.

The movie starts off with a 12 Monkeys vibe because the opening scene is a glimpse of the past. Tell me you all saw that movie. It is one of the best of all time. The pacing is slow with long looks and minimal dialogue, but the tech is sleek and sexy. Everything is white or feels white, clean, even the ruins, but then darkness and unknowns are thrown in, which is the least flashy way a movie can create conflict and I loved it. Quiet spooky stuff. Then the music came into play, and I was thrown into a Terminator vibe. Very futuristic everyone is going to die via machine kind of way. I loved it! I was completely creeped out. Tom played one of his most subdued roles ever, almost funny at times. Morgan Freemen excels at that and he did here too. There's a mystery to be solved, humanity to save, and the last man on earth to get laid. Okay, Tom's not the last man on earth, but here he is getting some and the world has ended! That was a little too much, but at least it was very understated, which pays respect to how sci-fi movies should be. Except when it comes to the modern version of Battlestar Galatica. They had the best sex scenes.

4.5 stars for Oblivion and I'm sure I'll watch it again because it's that cool. One more movie vibe reference. Wall-E. Weird, but let me know if you see what I'm saying here.

They should turn the concept of this movie into a TV series.  I think it is just that good!  I find myself watching this movie over and over (like I do with the Star Wars movies).  You can tell this movie was done with a lot of pride and attention to detail--that goes for the crew and the cast both.  And the musical scoring is powerful, in my opinion.  The visual effects--let's just say "eye candy!"  They're so excellent!  All of this is why I keep putting the disc back into my BD player for continued encore performances!!  The picture quality of this BD is stunning!  The sound quality is uber-fantastic if you have a DTS-HD Master Audio A/V receiver with a 7.1-channel surround sound system.  The soundtrack has great lows (the windows in the house vibrate on certain scenes).  I'd recommend this movie to anybody--especially if you like sci-fi and action!  This movie is underrated.  It's a glorious gem!
This movie was boring.  I found nothing exciting about it.  Not much more I can say except to advise you to wait until it becomes Prime and watch it for free.  You won't be missing much.

Blu-ray DVD for great price, quick shipping.  wouldn't pay this in the strore.
Movie is must for sci-fy fans.  enjoy

Tom Cruise delivers an outstanding and exciting movie about the maintenance of the machines after the world total destruction.  Scenes of famous landmarks in the US shows what the world has become without people.  Movie keeps you entertained, with many interesting and unusual aspects occurring during the course of the movie.  It is a very interesting movie ending; dealing with the extremely limited remaining mankind, and the power of the human mind and its ever-lasting spirit.

This futuristic set movie does a great job of presenting technology and human interaction that is credible for the future dates in which it is set.  The story and plot are very well thought out and complex enough to keep your full attention and interest.  The acting was good.  I was thoroughly absorbed and entertained.  The ending was good and appropriate to the movie.

Great storyline, but sometimes it was tough to keep up with it.
Freeman and Cruise handled their roles in the usual manner.

I thought this movie would be pretty good considering it starred Tom Cruise. Throughout the movie I kept waiting for it to get started and for things to start happening and for well...action. Unfortunately the movie droned on for just over 2 hours with the last 10 minutes being the best out of the entire movie. Could have been made in either half the time or could have just been made better period.
I thought the plot was a bit transparent. The story wasn't that compelling. The visual effects were outstanding. I don't think I'll pay for it again, but if it were free I'd watch.

Had an interesting plot, but was over acted and several of the scenes were too long.  It was entertaining, but I could have done a one time rental and been happy with never watching it again.  I did pick up a one-liner from the movie that I use out with friends...  "Are you still an effective team?"

Strange movie, I don't know why I liked it but I did... I suppose reading whatever it was based on might button up some of the background and such.

But it was a decent movie from an entertainment point of view... but seriously did anyone think the woman they reported to was real?

Hey any chance to see Olga Kurylenko, loved her since Hitman, is worth the risk!
This was a good scifi flick.  Not quite your average Tom Cruise action movie with a little touch of vanilla sky for good measure
The effects were fabulous, love Morgan Freeman and his character. The woman who played his real wife is so lovable simple and sincere. An interesting and most plausible storyline.

Wow!  I am not normally a Tom Cruise fan, but I was amazed by his acting in this one.  Subtle, surprising, even charming.  And, can I just say, he looks so good for his age!!  He's my dad's age, but he looks great. So, anyway, movie.  I love sci-fi stuff like this, and was surprised by a couple plot twists.  The soundtrack is incredible and visually it's just a treat to watch.  I will buy this movie (and the soundtrack) and plan on enjoying it quite often.  I think it would be over the head of kids, but quite clean (just one scene to skip to keep it completely kid friendly).  Definitely try it out - I don't think you'll be disappointed.

With visually compelling scenery and a captivating storyline, "Oblivion" is an interested movie with overtures of "vanilla sky"/things aren't what they seem.  I liked Cruise in this a lot, he does an excellent job of carrying the story with believable acting.  His co-stars added a lot, both the two women and Morgan Freeman.

It's a 'big' sci-fi story that's captured in less than two hours, would be interesting to see more backstory from human survivors/'matrix' perspective. Would've definitely liked to have seen more of Morgan Freeman's excellent acting in this, there was undoubtably a lot more that we could have seen had it been in the script.  Overall editing/dp/scriptwriting was compelling, well shot. The lake scene provided perfect green contrast to the white/silver mech home that Cruise's character works from.  Engaging and well done, without a lot of constant explosions and split-second jumpcuts that characterize other modern sci-fi movies, this one's well worth watching. A sci-fi gem that gets you to actually Think (like Vanilla Sky did), in a good way.  Nice work - well filmed, written and acted.

-ken
good movie liked it i enjoyed the movie  the special affects were great looking foward in seeing more movies in the future
You won't be disappointed.  There is a scene I use to show off the surround sound where they discover the personnel carriers being targeted by the drones.  Pretty awesome.

Full disclosure.  I like Tom Crusie and I love the Sci-Fi genre so I am bias in recommending this movie highly.  That being said, the plotline is plausible for the imagination and the CGI work was very good.
Complex yet gratifying, D-E-F-I-N-I-T-E-L-Y had matrix undertones, but it worked. The human species will survive!! Rent it don't buy, or not

This movie could be greater in two or three ways.

1. It's a sci fi and it needed more visual appeal as a Sci-fi should have. The only futuristic thing in this movie is the bike, his ship, the drones, his gun, the alien mothership, and the facility he lived in. I wanted to see more explosions, more scenery, and more technology. This brings to my next point. If he's in the future and he's flying an alien technological ship, why would lightning affect its system? Here's another question, where in the hell did Kara the alien triangle come from?

2. It lacked action. If you're going to create a movie where it's mostly story, make it worth watching from beginning to end and I wouldn't care about action. BUT, because this has more story then action it is obvious that it needed to deliver more ACTION. (Hope that makes sense)

Anyhow my review doesn't mean that the movie was bad, but it could have done a lot more for my buck. If you're wondering if it's worth watching, I say yes.

This move was fun to watch , for the plot, and the video was good quality and at the same time filtered in a way that made it draw you in. The sound quality was quite good as well. The drones will give many of your speakers a workout.

***spoilers possible***
Tom Cruise really needs to start picking roles that don't require the name "Jack". In this one, he's Jack Harper, a tech sent around to repair drones. The movie is set in a post-war future where "we" won but the earth was nearly destroyed in the process.

Our hero ends up teaming up with the last vestiges of true humanity and fighting for the freedom of the planet. The dream scenes are kind of a stretch as are some of the major plot points, but if you consider that most science fiction things are farfetched, it becomes reasonable.

There were plenty of times in the movie where I just wanted it to get to a point, but overall, it's an okay sci-fi flick. I wouldn't add it to my list of top 100 movies ever made or even put it on my Christmas wish list, but it's worth seeing once or twice if you're a fan of science fiction films.
This was a great sci-fi movie. I was still pondering it in the days following.  Very thought provoking.  A fun movie.

It was an interesting movie.  Was trying to figure it out and was very pleased at the way they brought it all together in the end.  We're going to buy the move because it is one of those movies that you find more and more each time you watch it.
Very unexpected twist to this one.  LOVED IT!!!  Definitely expect a sequel to this one.  Tom and Morgan just AWESOME!!!
I've watched it a few times and will watch it more. GREAT special effects and a great story line.  ENJOY
An intriguing story set in the future combined with A-1 special effects, plus a nice twist at the end provided a very pleasant viewing experience.

I almost went to see this movie in the theater, but ended up passing it by.  I bought the Blu-ray and was expecting a strictly action/sci-fi movie with a lot of cool visuals and not a lot of plot.  I was right about the action and visuals, they are great in Oblivion.  However, the plot is what really surprised me.
It went from being a good action movie to a GREAT "thinking" movie.  Kinda like Inception or a similar movie where it really makes you stop and say, wait a minute, what's going on here...
I love movies that have an interesting and dynamic deep storyline, and Oblivion ends up having that. Personally, for my movie taste, I loved it, and it is definitely a movie that you will get more out of by watching it more than once.  I highly recommend it for people that like a good action/sci-fi type movie that also has a lot of storyline thought put into it.

Plenty of action. It didn't get that good of a rating when it was in theaters. I thought it was very good.

I have been a science fiction fan since I was small and there are certain sci-fi books and movies that are on my roster of all-time favorites (Matrix, Terminator movies, 2001, A Space Odyssey, Minority Report, Avatar, Doctor Who (I'm a Brit), Neil Gaiman, Asimov books, some Heinlein, Ender's Game are a few that come to mind) and Oblivion has joined the list.

In my view, it's a highly aesthetic film with a good story and good acting. To me a movie like Oblivion is what movie making is about: good plot with a story you can't guess (not sure what the critics' comments about being derivative were about, I have read and seen plenty of sci-fi, and the story had me surprised), good CGI and effects, great, original accompanying music, good acting and some amazing, breathtaking scenes; like the protagonists' home in the sky and their swimming pool suspended amongst the clouds; the sweeping vistas of a post-apocalyptic earth (with a tip of the Empire State building showing) and flight scenes between Manhattan streets-turned ravines.

Tom Cruise did a great job, he was believable and charismatic at the same time. The other actors, less well-known to me by name other than Morgan Freeman, acted their parts well and believably. Thanks to the Oblivion team for bringing a truly great science fiction movie to the screen.

The entire cast actually did a good job. I actually liked the plot of the film and it made for an interesting storyline that was entertaining.  It had enough twists and turns to keep you thinking.

I think the film was much better than many people give it credit. I won't go into any spoilers but the film is worth watching at least once and for the special effects maybe even twice. It is an interesting Sci-Fi story.  This is the reason I watch movies.

I do wish that there was more interaction with the invading aliens and that part of the storyline could had been enhanced and it would had made the film even better. For me the film was about a 4.5 but since that rating is not allowed I will make if a 5 star. I would watch it again.

Last time he played a character that I liked was in Interview with a Vampire, so I wasn't surprised at the lackluster performance in Oblivion.  Everyone just seemed to walk from one scene to the next, feeling nothing and portraying NONE of the emotional hell that the situation would call for had it been real-life.

I am astounded; as graphics increase, acting ability decreases on the same scale.

Actually there are special features included with this movie...

Bonus Features on Blu-rayTM and DVD:

- Feature Commentary with Tom Cruise and director Joseph Kosinski
 - Deleted Scenes
 - Promise of a New World: The Making of OblivionA comprehensive and thought-provoking multi-part feature covering the making of Oblivion, including:
 - Destiny  Looks inside the conceptualization, development and pre-production of Oblivion and the planning that went into the Herculean task of shooting the epic film.
 - Voyage  Follows the creation of the amazing Bubble Ship from its early design conception to its journey around the world. (Blu-ray exclusive)
 - Combat  Explores the film's ground-breaking action and death-defying stunts, all performed by one of the most popular movie stars in the world. (Blu-ray exclusive)
 - Illusion  Focuses on the film's post-production and dazzling visual effects.
- Harmony  Delves into the innovative musical world of M83.
 - M83 Isolated ScoreWatch the entire film accompanied by the evocative music track.

Oblivion is a 2013 American post-apocalyptic science fiction film based on Joseph Kosinski's Radical Comics-edited unpublished graphic novel of the same name. The film was co-written, produced and directed by Kosinski.

I would rate this film a "B-". The special effects seemlessly created a post-apocalyptic Earth and a dystopian future that has the audience asking early on, "what's going on here?" While I had some suspicions about the plot line, the tale was not quite as predictable as I had thought.

Overall, this is an engaging flick but nothing to nominate for the Oscars.

When you have seen as many movies as I have you tend to become jaded. You wonder if an original blockbuster-type movie will ever be made with genuine effort and a non-ironic purpose, especially in the sci-fi genre. You fear the day will never come. It is nice to be proven wrong.

Oblivion is not a fantastic movie by any means. It has its problems. There are some inconsistencies and goofs here and there, but you can tell from the first few minutes that genuine thought and effort was put in to this movie, and that more than makes up for its other issues. There is a style and an atmosphere to it. In a time when green-screen rooms are substituted for real sets so often that you begin to worry for the livelihoods of studio carpenters, here is a film which "feels" real. These are sets and locations that, though parts of them were C.G., there was a seamless blending with the real that is a treat for computer weary eyes.

Tom Cruise plays Jack Harper, a technician responsible for the maintenance and security of huge reactors that supply power to off-world colonists. Earth has been nearly destroyed by an invading alien force and, though humanity won the war, the planet is a wasteland. This is explained by a helpful (if annoying) voice over/scroll at the beginning of the film. Jack's only company is his communications officer Victoria (Andrea Riseborough) with whom he occasionally gets frisky. Their memories are periodically erased to protect vital off-world information in case of capture by the remnants of the alien force which they call "Scavs". In spite of their memory wipes Jack has flashes of his life from before the war, which worries him because the war ended sixty years ago, well before he was born.

His companion tells him to focus on his work and not to worry. After all, they are leaving for the new colony in two weeks and they don't want to ruin their chance to rejoin humanity. The work continues as usual until an encounter with the Scavs and the discovery of a crashed spaceship shake everything Jack thinks he knows.

From here we would enter into spoiler territory, so I will dispense with the exposition. Suffice it to say that what follows, while not perfect, at least shows true effort at the writing, acting, directing, and effects levels. The actors really care about what they are doing and it shows. Tom Cruise, of course, can only play Tom Cruise. His range is limited, but here it is well used. The mystery of the plot, while a little predictable, at least doesn't insult the viewer's intelligence. In a limited fashion the movie brings up questions about what it means to be human and what our purpose really is in the world. Though these issues are not delved into too deeply, it was nice to see them actually dealt with and not just used as cheap set pieces. The set designers and the director take care to create a world we can dive into and almost touch and taste. The sterility of Jack's base really contrasts with the grittiness of the devastated world below.

The only items I would change are relatively minor. One is the opening scroll/narration. Opening scrolls may have been cool in Star Wars a few decades ago, but now they are a little dated and annoying. They are especially grating when read aloud to us and doubly so when you divulge the exact same information with dialogue not too long after. The other change would be to distinguish between the female leads physically a little better. Because of the washed out color scheme of the movie it is hard to tell the two women apart at times and it gets distracting. Is that her? No, wait. It's the other one. The fact that the two women are usually in different styles of clothing and in different locations helps, but it takes a while to get there.

This is a movie well worth the effort put into it. It is good sci-fi with good execution and no franchise to prop it up. The studio went out on a limb by not playing it safe and finding something to reboot or a big name to tag a sequel onto. Here's hoping this movie gets a lot of attention and maybe we will see more of its kind in the future.

Somehow every title starring Tom Cruise seems to offer more action than story.  (Don't these screen heroes get enough exercise at the gym?)  Even so... Tom's futuristic control complex hovers over a desolate, post-apocolyptic ruin that's still occupied by unknown entities, and he's gotta monitor for activites down there to make sure it's all cool.  An excessively convoluted plot follows him back and forth from the surface where he's variously perplexed, shocked, challenged, accosted, duplicated, killed, and restored, finally to an idylic existence in a quaint, green little country setting with the girl of his dreams, in a way that will leave your head spinning. In the end I was left wanting more - character development, robust story, action, almost anything.  The best part about the movie is the visuals and CGI - these are quite stunning and done incredibly well.  Overall, the movie is about the survival of humanity, but the film feels very far from anything human or real to me.

This sci-fi thriller unfolds like a novel, with a deliberate pace, each revelation building upon the other. Jack Harper is part of a two person team left behind on a desolated Earth after a war against an alien race. Mankind has relocated to Titan. Jack and his partner's job is to maintain the drones that protect the power generators sucking energy from Earth's oceans to power life on faraway Titan. Neither Jack nor his partner have a memory more than five years old, but Jack is haunted by dreams of a previous life, dreams that focus on a beautiful woman and visions of Earth before the war. Soon we begin to see that all is not as it seems.

Despite the measured pace, the stunning visuals hold your interest: visually this film is a triumph. There are enough big action scenes to keep it exciting, although the movie begins to look familiar in parts, paying homage to Star Wars, Independence Day, The Matrix, and any post-apocalyptic thriller you've ever seen (I'm talking about you, Mad Max).

This movie requires you to think and remember in order to understand the final revelations, so if you aren't the sort of person who likes puzzle movies, you might want to avoid this one.

This film is a fairy tale and I guarantee you it will end well. But it is also a patchwork of plagiarized elements.

The earth was destroyed, a destruction caused by the destruction of the moon by some not really specified cosmic war. The earth then turned into a wasteland submerged by tons and tons of dust, earth and rocks. The ruins are thus underground. The Golden Gate Bridge is reduced to two pillar tips sticking out of that dirt. That's a rewriting of H.G. Wells the Time Machine.

Two humans are living in the ring of satellites that overlook the waste land with a company of drones that are supposed to destroy all signs of life. Jack Harper is the man and the woman is supposed to be his wife. Jack Harper's memory has been erased to enable him to carry out his mission. Total Recall, second episode, the sequel. Everyday Jack Harper is supposed to go down on the surface to revive the drones that have been downed in the night. There is thus some kind of hostile life on this planet, living underground of course. That's Star Wars revisited. An underground resistance has been so often used that listing all the plagiarized connections would take many pages. That implies at this moment that the surviving humans who have fled the decaying planet are controlling the situation from some distant artificial planet. That is a black star like in Star Wars again. But who are these escapees?

But memory-deprived Jack Harper knows where there is a secret valley that is as primeval as the Garden of Eden. There Jack Harper has a cabin with electricity and a pile of vinyl records and a record player and all kinds of heirloom  and he plays his records everyday when he manages to escape from the control of his "wife" on the surveillance satellite. The drones have never found that place. I guess Jack Harper's lost memory was not lost completely and the drones are not very swift.

Then one day a spacecraft crushes on the surface and there are four or five sleep-boxes with hibernating human beings in them. This spacecraft was called by a strange signal from the underground resistance. The drones are destroying the sleep-pods. Jack Harper saves one and takes the woman inside to his satellite base. The reaction of his official wife shows there is a real problem there. When he takes the woman to recuperate the "black box" of the space craft they are captured by the resistance and then things become iffy.

Let's have one more trip "Back to the Future" and then we have two Jack Harpers and maybe or maybe not two women and this saved woman (or her and her double) is revealed to be Jack Harper's real wife, two real wives and two real Jack Harpers. Then the initial Jack Harper recuperates some kind of memory. With the help of the resistance under attack from drones, he realizes that he has to fulfill the mission the other Jack Harper - but that is him in a way, at least if you accept the concept of doppelgangers - and  his wife were entrusted with: to destroy the black star.

Officially one of his real wives is hidden in the secret valley, the other one is set in the sleep pod that is going to be delivered by one Jack Harper to the black star with a bomb in it. When he finally reaches his destination, o divine miracle, the wife has been swapped and replaced by the leader of the resistance who is dying of a wound gotten in the last battle against the drones. But the bomb is here, Jack Harper is determined and the final an massive attack of drones against the resistance is under way.

What will happen? A happy happening and glorious ending of course. The black star crumbles, the drones are grounded, the resistance is saved, the wife has a child and two or three years later the surviving Jack Harper reaches the secret valley with the resistance and we are in a Grimm-like ending when they are happy ever after, ever after Snow White's step mother dies dancing in red-hot metal shoes.

If you like soft horror fairy tales, rush to this one. Otherwise entrust it to your children who might have soft nightmares in the night. You will have to cuddle them with love.

Dr Jacques COULARDEAU

Actually, Tom Cruise has come back to Earth (in real life) and his being cast in a Sci-Fi movie occurring right here on earth is quite appropriate. But I love a good Sci-Fi movie and this one is pretty good. It evokes emotions like 2001 Space Odyssey. Beautiful. You don't like the acting? What are you comparing it to? Its Tom Cruise. Hey, he does all his own stunts, convincingly. He's no J. Nicholson or A. Hopkins but he's not a bad actor. I'm glad he's come back to reality (again, in real life). You think there is too much CGI? Too Digital? Again, what are you comparing it to? Are you sure you knew you were watching a Sci-Fi movie? Actually if you watch the "Making of" on the blu-ray it explains there is a lot more "reality" in the movie than you might think and less CGI. But its a modern science fiction movie. CGI is required to tell the story, but I think this movie is a perfect balance. The drones are the coolest, even though they are villains. I love the noises they make... kind of like R2-D2 on steroids. The score is fantastic. You can watch the movie with only the score playing. That's a little weird, but the score can probably stand on its own if you are into just listening to a movie soundtrack by itself. One question I have about one of the characters, Vika, is why are her eyes so dilated all the time? It is spooky looking. Why I am writing a review of this movie that hundreds of people have already given their dumb opinions of, I don't know. Just thought I would offer mine because I liked it so much. Besides the movie, the "making of" is a very interesting documentary. Its in 5 parts and in HD as well. Its almost as good as the movie itself. I own the blu-ray and the video is of outstanding quality. Can't comment on the audio since I have not watched it with surround.

I rented this since I am a Cruise fan and pretty much see all his stuff automatically. After viewing it, I bought the blu-ray--I knew I would want to see it several more times. While I actually liked the story, I was particularly drawn to all the sets--the house in the sky, the pool, the earth landscape, the cool plane he flies, even the drones. I found it easy to become immersed in that world....which made the actual story less important. Watching the extra features greatly enhanced my enjoyment as well. A LOT of work went into making this movie look the way it does. Five stars all around from me.

Edited to add: I notice that a lot of reviews are complaining that it was too digitized and too many special effects. How ironic that the producers would go to such lengths for realism (as shown in the extra features).....and they were so successful that the assumption is that it's all fake! The vast barren earth scenes are real, shot in Iceland. The scenes out the windows of the sky house are actual photographs of clouds and sunrise/set, projected onto a 360-degree screen surrounding the house (no blue or green screens). Surprisingly little of this film was CGI.

I expected another over-the-top ho-hum shoot 'em up/blow 'em up Tom Cruise sci-fi romp.  Instead, this is a well-thought out and masterfully executed effort that is strongly character driven, romantic, and a spectacular audio visual experience. It is absolutely incredible to watch on the big screen.  The sound mix is near perfect because you almost never think about it. It concentrates on immersing you in the story rather than taking you on an amusement park ride.

Cruise delivers, but the female leads also deliver moving performances. I highly recommend that you watch the extras on the making of the movie, and watch it again with the running commentary where director Kosinski and Cruise give you insight and nuance to the story and its twists.  From this, it's clear that Cruise just does not phone it in; that he was deeply immersed in the success of the project. They also discuss how many of the amazing visuals are much more "real" than we would anticipate in this green screen age...which accounts for much of its impressiveness.

There are a lot of flying sequences which are all extremely well done. If you watch the behind the scenes extras, you'll find out how they did it. The in-cockpit effects with the actors are the best I've ever seen, and as a former fighter pilot, I can tell you that it adds exceptional realism physically and in the influence on the actors' performances.

I agree that the visuals have an entirely different experience depending on the size of the screen you watch. This movie was designed for the big screen, and there is depth to detail that just cannot be seen on the small screen. Close-ups of actors are deeply immersive on the big screen because of the insanely sharp definition and depth in actors' eyes due to the cinematography and new HD camera and lenses. When emotion is high, this becomes an amazingly powerful tool in this film.

Find a friend with a front projection home theater and bring the popcorn.
Really a pretty good movie. Not action packed but kept you interested. You knew something was up with clues they give you but not quite sure what until the end of the movie. Keeps you guessing.

This movie was very suspenseful. It kept me guessing on what was really going on. I actually was very surprised at the outcomes. It was not predictable.

This movie is 'high' Sci-Fi, as opposed to 'low' Sci-Fi.  What this means is this :  It's meant to provoke you to think and ponder the prospects of the story's scenario.  Therefore, it's a GREAT Sci-Fi for true Sci-Fi fans, whereas, it may not be well suited for someone whose expecting your normal Tom Cruise type action movie.  Though it has really good action, it's more a Sci-Fi drama than an action movie.  The effects and production value are TOP NOTCH.  The director was very good, as was the acting.

The movie kind of leaves you hanging with all sorts of unanswered questions, and, for me at least, this is not a bad thing.  I was left wanting to know more about what happened before the movie's time frame, as well as after.  In fact, I'd bet that if they did a part 2 based on what occurred BEFORE the movie's time-frame, it'd be great to see !

The robotic sentries in the movie actually stole a few scenes they were in...they were truly well depicted, and, for the first time an any film I've seen, a robotic presence actually felt scary...scary because incredibly capable, tough, and ruthless.

Don't hesitate to see this movie.  Cruise does a great job, and his character ends up being quite complex and human.  The effects are beautiful to behold.  In fact, this movie is a pleasure to behold because the lighting and effects are at times staggeringly beautiful.  No cheese in this movie.  No filler either.  I only wish it could have covered a bit more terrain in relation to its core conception of story and related events.  But I'm not complaining.

Visually interesting but with endless plot holes such as contamination concerns (but you never saw Cruise taking any precautions- except an ordinary shower when he got home). What's to be concerned about? Earth was destroyed but various structure still stand, maybe buried under a LOT of soil, but standing- yeah, right.

I think I figure out the alien angle before it was revealed, stupid aliens usually did a sloppy job of tracking Cruise- almost laughable.

I may buy a copy someday, there is a visual appeal if you check your brain at the door, but I'll need some of those extras I've heard about and I don't see them here.

I'm a Tom Cruise fan, but this is not one of his better films.  It's okay--Tom Cruise  being Tom Cruise in a lackluster walk through of the movie.  I think he saw the boredom of the story at hand, but was anxious to collect his paycheck on the way out.

The story has potential, but this was not fully realized by the screenwriters.  After  a while I found myself saying lines before they were said and predicting what would happen next.  Nothing too original here.

Set and effects were okay, but we've seen it all before in better films.  Fairly dumb action sequences.  This is a film with a lot of gaps in logic where some things occur to show technology of the future, but then don't work later to show how heroic our hero is.

I've never been a fan of Tom Cruise but the man can act. Oblivion is a good example of that. It started amazing: the plot is fresh, new, innovative, nothing we've seen before. I was extremely thankful for the novelty factor. The visuals are highly engaging and well done. The pacing is just right. Not too slow, but it also doesn't jump right in without any information on the background.
I won't discuss the plot because others have done that already. Let's just say, it's worth buying the DVD. I know I'll watch it again in the near future, not least because the acting was outstanding and the twists were nothing I expected.
What I didn't like was the ending. It was too...much. I won't say what it is so I won't spoil it for those who haven't watched the movie but I wish the directors/producers/writers didn't go overboard with it because it could have been a five-star movie.
Still enjoyable though and a solid three stars.

Instead I tend to think of him saying to himself in his head "Well that dangerous stunt that I just did myself was really manly of me!" and "People will really think of me as a manly man now!" And then I will usually notice the actors that are taller than him.

Hugh Jackman, Gerard Butler, Daniel Craig, Guy Pearce, Chris Hemsworth, Channing Tatum, Matt Damon, Brad Pitt, Vin Diesel, Matthew McConaughey, Mark Wahlberg any of these guys or whoever your favorite male actor is could've played Tom's character.

So when you watch it, picture your favorite or one of these guys in his place & you'll like the movie even better!

Say what you will about Tom Cruise - and of his off-screen persona, most of what I'd have to say would be negative - but he is a great actor, who almost always delivers; and this is one of his best performances. This is a thinking man's science fiction flick...not only is it visually stunning with some nifty CGI special effects, it also has an intelligently written script, with dialogue that is ofttimes poetic, as the opening quote exemplifies. Set in 2077, 60 years after Earth is invaded by alien beings called Scavengers (Scavs), who destroy the Moon, resulting in a tectonic upheaval, that - combined with nuclear weapons, used to defeat the aliens, have resulted in Earth becoming virtually uninhabitable. The remaining humans inhabit a huge space station and have established a colony on Titan, one of the moons of Saturn. Cruise as Jack Harper, is Tech 49, who is responsible for patrolling the radiation-free sections of Earth and for maintenance of drone warships that hunt down the remaining Scavs. He is assisted by his communications officer and lover, Victoria (Andrea Riseborough). At the end of one of his patrols, the Odyssey, a NASA spaceship crashes and in the only survivor is a mysterious female, Julia (Olga Kurylenko). But things are not exactly as they seem. Be prepared for some surprises, beginning with the appearance Julia and Malcolm Beech (Morgan Freeman) who leads an underground stronghold of...humans. Produced, directed and written by Joseph Kosinski, he gets triple credit for its excellence. If you love the genre as much as I do, you will love this outstanding sci/fi flick.

Why are the dreams so vivid yet not reality?
Why must mankind leave the Earth even though the alien invaders were defeated?
Why are the murderous Scavs suddenly interested in capturing Jack?
As the movie progresses with spectacular special effects (Jack's home, Jack's aircraft, the drones, the buried cities), the answers to the mysteries are slowly revealed to Jack.  The story is told through Jack's eyes and his emotions are almost directly felt.
Some of the answers are truly surprises.  These lead to even bigger puzzles, especially for the audience.
Overall the movie was great entertainment with great visuals, music, a thrilling story.
The back-story of the aliens and their invasion of Earth is sorely needed to completely understand why things are happening as they are.  This is for another movie though.

This film started out great and it looks great. If it only had a plot or gave some hint of why a big triangle rock in space would want to kill all the humans on planet Earth. Why would Morgan Freeman and a band of rebels dress up like the Predator? Because the space rock in the sky sent out droids to kill humans and Scavs. Why wear the sweaty helmet? The clone thing was odd. So, Jack and his copilot on the space mission let the passengers escape when they flew into the big space rock. They must have been the only ones ever to make it because the space rock cloned them. Then sent them out to find downed droids on planet Earth. This movie is pretty to look at but, it left me with a lot of questions. If one clone gets blown up am I really happy another clone comes back? Jack loses his copilot/dispatcher for droid repair but finds his wife from his Earth life. He moves on rather quickly. Then she returns the favor by going through the original Jack, one clone, and another clone at the end. Kinda crazy.

I read a few of the reviews before watching this movie, and I almost did not watch it. I am glad I did. I read that the plot did not make sense. I think the plot makes perfect sense, and is interesting as well as ingenious as well as sweet. I will make one small criticism: the perfect home and machines that the 2 humans live and work in seem too perfect to be true ( but I think that the alien tech entity could easily maintain them ) Another small complaint: we are supposed to believe that this fantastic technological entity still needs humans to repair some of the machines ( I believe that this is probable, just look at our own world, machines are always breaking down ). And one other small criticism: We only see one small group of survivors ( actually, I prefer this. Some movies, like the matrix, try to show too much and thereby become less interesting ). So you see that all my criticisms actually are not criticisms at all. This story is solid, well told, moves along swiftly, and is continually interesting. Even the schmaltzy parts are perfect. There is one small but important scene which cries out for the perfect soundtrack song. I found myself thinking that this would be the perfect place to play A Whiter Shade Of Pale... and it plays!!!! The inevitable ending has two ( TWO ) surprises that actually took me by surprise. I felt warm and happy and satisfied.

Everything in this movie is perfect. The music is amazing, the actors are perfect for their roles, the storyline is astonishing and surprising, and the movie itself is so visually stunning.

In the year 2077, aliens attacked earth. They were defeated, but earth was completely destroyed. Rome, London, New York City; all lie beneath hundreds of feet of sand and rubble. The TET is collecting survivors for transport to one of Saturn's moons, Titan. Jack and Vicka remain below, handling logistics and repairing drones and hydro-reactors that are converting the earth's oceans into energy for the colony in Titan.

That's all I can tell you; you have to watch the movie. It is so incredibly well put together. The storyline holds you in suspense and mystery for a very long time, and the climactic scene is simply epic. I cannot compliment this movie enough.

However, the ending is a bit disappointing, so just stop the movie about 2 minutes before then.

The movie has a mix of tense action scenes, interesting futuristic living scenes, and discovery scenes that thoroughly entertain.  The acting, settings, visual effects--all are astounding.  You WILL immerse yourself in this futuristic world.

SPOILER ALERT! I start by stating that I like Tom Cruise in science fiction (see "Minority Report") because he is not being "Tom Cruise," ("I must protect my wingman.").  The premise was interesting enough, and begs the question,"If you were the only one in the Matrix, would you care?"  The bleak scenery espouses the isolation the characters experience, and the technology is believable future tech, but the acting lacked passion.  Perhaps the casting of the clone wife with someone with an upper crust British accent and attitude could have been done with someone with more personality. Also, the fact that she too is a clone was a bit disappointing.  If she had been in on the deception, there would have been more suspense. But in the end, she had no control over her own behavior. It is only Cruise's flawed cloning, which leaves him with a thread of residual memory that nags him at night that something is rotten in Denmark, that opens the door to a resolution.  In this aspect of the story, I would have liked to seen more told from the scavenger's perspective.  All we know is that they took "decades" to find the ship with Criuse's real wife orbiting in stasis, but how did they know he was having memory dreams, and that the sight of his lost love would 'awaken the sleeper'?  We assume there were at least 52 clones, obviously necessary to cover the Earth.  Perhaps they captured one.  It would have nice if Mr. Freeman's character had told us, as Morpheus told Neo of the first person to escape the Matrix. In the end, Oblivion was an pleasant diversion, but not one I would repeat.  It's no Matrix.
Tom Cruise does his usual stand up job at playing a hero. Morgan makes you actually care, unlike number 42's wife.

There were also a few rather confusing moments that didn't add anything useful or effective (such as suspense, for example). My favorite parts were perhaps what seemed to be nods to Top Gun.

An Earth laid waste, debris and dust al around with one lone technician doing what he can to keep things running. No, not Wall*E, but Tom Cruise as Jack (Tech 49) repairing the drones left behind to protect giant energy convertors, all that is left of use on Earth. In this, Tech-49 is aided by Andrea Riseborough in their austere home in the clouds. At the start of the movie, Jack is clearly more philosophical troubled by what they do than she is, but this is overshadowed by a greater disturbance in their routine when Jack finds a survivor, played by Olga Kurylenko, which forces Jack to reassess all he knows about his mission. First off, the design is just fantastic.. it's a beautifully detailed world, a believably scorched earth in contrast with their sleek minimalist modern living environment. It's clear that throw cushions and terracotta are not in fashion in the future. Also, the director Joseph Kosinski (Tron: Legacy (Two-Disc Blu-ray/DVD Combo)) has once again used a contemporary soundtrack which manages to be both epic and modern adding an energy to the movie that it might not have had with a more conventional symphonic score. Tom Cruise never quite escapes being Tom Cruise, making it hard for us to invest in his character, but Andrea Riseborough more than makes up for it with a character so buttoned up that her expressions of emotion need only be the slightest of moments to make a great impact - it's a great performance. Kurylenko never feels quite at home in her role here, but passes muster. Morgan Freeman - well, who can say that watching Morgan freeman isn't a pleasure, but he is hardly stretched in what turns out to be quite a minor role. Great entrance though, which focusses on his distinctive voice before he is revealed in person. At the end of that short monologue, Freeman says `Lights' and the greater picture is revealed... and that sort of sums up the direction. After every moment of characterisation, we swiftly move past to reach a reveal of some greater plot or art design, which sort of shows you where the director's heart really is. He's more interested in the big ideas, than where his characters are coming from or going to. Many of those ideas in the movie are not original - you get the feeling in the movie frequently of `Oh, that's just like in the movie `insert movie here'.. (it would be churlish to name the movie references and spoil the fun of finding them for yourself). However, it's been put together in such a stylish way and with such conviction from the director, that it's a success. Ultimately it's good to see stylish thoughtful sci-fi gracing the big screen, and I for one give it a thumbs up.
