Joseph Kosinski

Writing credits
Joseph Kosinski (screenplay) and
Karl Gajdusek (screenplay) and
Michael Arndt (screenplay)

Cast

Tom Cruise ... Jack

Morgan Freeman ... Beech

Olga Kurylenko ... Julia

Andrea Riseborough ... Victoria

There may be spoilers.

Some critics have panned this new film from director and co-writer Joseph Kosinski, in this his second film ("TRON: Legacy"), as being highly derivative.  But let's face it, how many films are so fresh and new that they delve into uncharted territory?  In any case, don't care.  Whether it's a drama, a comedy, a horror movie or even a romantic comedy, it's how well it is delivered that counts.  And this film delivers.

Like "TRON" the film is visually arresting.  Seen on a big screen, the sets are huge but sparse, drawing the audience in.  Set in a war-ravaged Earth of 2077 devoid of humans, all of whom have resettled on a moon of Saturn, only Jack (terrific Tom Cruise) and Victoria (Andrea Riseborough) remain.  They are partners (both romantic and professionally) whose mission is to watch over the drones that patrol the area for a smattering of "Scavs" who were the defeated invaders.  While Earth won the war, they lost the planet which continues to be harvested for water and other ecological matter.

Jack is the investigative repair man who goes out alone.  Victoria never leaves their high control point and guides him using sophisticated tracking technology.  While investigating an unusual radio beacon, Jack witnesses a spacecraft crash.  One of the survivors is a human flight officer named Julia (Olga Kurylenko) who he has occasionally dreamed about.  Both Jack and Vic have had their memories "washed" in order to eliminate thoughts of the terrible war.  Uh, sure.  What Jack believes to be "Scavs" turns out to be Beech (Morgan Freeman) and his collection of survivors.  The truth is out there and Jack must find it, and does with the help of Julia.

Like "TRON,"  "Oblivion" is beautiful to watch and has a great soundtrack, mostly provided by French electronic band, M83.  Yes, "Oblivion" borrows from a list of movies too long to mention, but for those of us who salivate for science fiction films with a breath of intelligence, this one does the trick.

BLU RAY REVIEW: In this subsequent viewing of this terrific sci-fi film, I was able to tie up a few elements I didn't quite understand the first time around.  I would also have to say this is one of the best looking movies of any genre I've seen.  The special features on the Blu ray disc add some clarity on how and why the filmmakers went for a certain look and it truly comes across beautifully.

The other thing I had missed the first time around was the romantic relationship between Jack and Victoria and subsequently Julia.  It was there but just wasn't a point of focus.  By "there," I mean it wasn't explicit, either by subdued actions or love making.  Regarding the later, the most interesting coupling occurs in the swimming pool.  It seems clear that Jack's relationship with Victoria seems forced or maybe expected is a better word.  He does all the right things that husbands and wives do, but it seems like a matter of routine more than true love.  Watch Cruise's face during those intimate close ups.  Something is wrong.  Of course those memory flashbacks of Julia don't help.  When Jack finally does find Julia, it all clicks.  Not quickly, but you can see in Jack's reactions, he loves this woman.  But why?  In the end, he shows how much he loves her.  "Oblivion" is also a beautiful love story.

There is nothing like watching a beautiful movie like this on the big screen, but this Blu Ray transfer comes damn close.  The 1080p transfer is spectacular in every respect and certainly will be a show off piece to a good system.  It comes in the original aspect ratio of 2.39:1 and does a great job replicating the original film.  The dystopian world is now essentially uninhabited and the stark whites and various shades contrast nicely with deep dark blacks.  When the story moves underground, shadows and shadings of grey prevail.  But even when Jack retreats to his cabin in the wilderness, we get beautiful greens and various earth tones in all their splendor.  I could see no encoding issues.  The contrast and detail are excellent.

Equaling the visuals is a magnificent DTS-HD Master Audio 7.1 audio track.  Again put this one on your demo list.  If you have sub-woofers, they will get a workout as the rumbles coming from many sources including gunfire, rockets and explosions.  The surrounds are constantly in play with movement from side to side, back and forth as the drone ships fly around.  Dialog is clear and well presented.  Ambient noise is ever present as well.

Extras include an excellent commentary track by Tom Cruise and director Joseph Kosinski, a 48 minute "making of" documentary, some deleted scenes and get this, an isolated musical score by M83 in Dolby TruHD 5.1 (24 bit, 96kHz).  A great package to own.

I am a big sci-fi fan and was really looking forward to seeing Oblivion.  This sci-fi post apocalyptic earth movie has great computer graphics but my wife and I felt the movie was long and tedious even though it's only 125 minutes.  Even Tom Cruise and Morgan Freeman can only do so much to save this movie.

Hot-shot pilot moves in expensive, cutting edge fighter jets, wide-scenic shots of Tom Cruise on a motorcycle...get "Take My Breath Away" out of your head - we're talking about Oblivion here! While the similarities between Oblivion and Top Gun end at the aforementioned, there is no question that "Maverick" has all the right moves to portray galactic mechanic, Jack Harper in the most visually dazzling film of the year so far.

Oblivion opens in 2077 after an alien threat has left Earth a barren wasteland fit only for extracting a few vital resources before humanity abandons the planet altogether to start a new existence on Saturn's largest moon, Titan. Cruise's Harper is a glorified serviceman who supervises and repairs the various resource-extraction devices along with his partner Victoria (Andrea Riseborough). As the two near the completion of their jobs on Earth, Harper begins having visions of his life prior to the mandatory memory-wipe that is required for service-workers. These visions lead him on a chain of events that cause him to question everything he thought he knew about his life.

Director Joseph Kosinski creates a vividly rich and nuanced futuristic environment where much of the technology feels like what truly is on the horizon. Kosinski directed 2010's under-rated visual spectacle, Tron Legacy, and it is apparent that he has his finger on the pulse of crisp, sci-fi style. Narrative-wise, Oblivion is a much more complex story than is likely expected. The complexities do provide some depth to the film and force the audience to pay close attention; however, the juxtaposition between the style and the narrative is not smooth. Occasionally, the film is forced into a lull as it tries to tie up its intricate plot points without sacrificing its visual pageantry. This is most apparent in the scenes that develop the sub-plot involving a human resistance leader named Beech (Morgan Freeman) and a mysterious NASA survivor named Julia (Olga Kurylenko).

Oblivion's chief attributes are clearly its visual elements. Freeman and Kurylenko's characters are thinly developed and the actors are mostly unremarkable. However, it is becoming more and more apparent that any film that features Morgan Freeman in any role is most likely not a bad movie. Thematically, the film is successful at developing some intriguing ideas about discovery and purpose. The film acts as a subtle homage to familiar films like Alien, 2001: A Space Odyssey, and even Wall-E. Speaking of familiar, the score is oddly reminiscent of Christopher Nolan's Dark Knight films. This is simply an observation, but having Morgan Freeman in the film as well certainly makes one wonder if this is some form of statement. Regardless, while some will no doubt be puzzled or dissatisfied with the conclusion, Oblivion mostly works as an epic and visually alluring entry into the science-fiction canon. B+

On a side note, seeing the film in IMAX or an XTREME screen is recommended as the film has so much to offer visually. Oblivion is rated PG-13 and runs 125 minutes.

"Oblivion" is great! This is how the story goes: 2077: Jack Harper (Tom Cruise) serves as a security repairmen stationed on an evacuated Earth. Part of a massive operation to extract vital resources after decades of war with a terrifying alien threat who still scavenges what's left of our planet, Jack's mission is almost complete. In a matter of two weeks, he will join the remaining survivors on a lunar colony far from the war-torn world he has long called home.

Living in and patrolling the breathtaking skies from thousands of feet above, Jack's soaring existence is brought crashing down after he rescues a beautiful stranger from a downed spacecraft. Drawn to Jack through a connection that transcends logic, her arrival triggers a chain of events that forces him to question everything he thought he knew. With a reality that is shattered as he discovers shocking truths that connect him to Earth of the past, Jack will be pushed to a heroism he didn't know he contained within. The fate of humanity now rests solely in the hands of a man who believed our world was soon to be lost forever.

The cast led by Tom Cruise (as Jack Harper) & Morgan Freeman (as Beech) is great. The directing by Joseph Kosinski (who also produced & wrote the screenplay and the comic book of which the movie is based on) is great. The screenplay by Kosinski, Karl Gajdusek & Michael Arndt (which is based on the comic book by Kosinski & Arvid Nelson) is great.

The music by M83, Joseph Trapanese & Anthony Gonzalez is great. The cinematography by Claudio Miranda is great. The film editing by Richard Francis-Bruce is great. The casting by Marcia Ross is great. The production design by Darren Gilford is great. The art direction by Joseph Bahran, Todd Cherniawsky, James Clyne & Kevin Ishioka is great. The set decoration by Ronald R. Reiss, set designs by Steve Cooper, Joseph Hiura, Robert Andrew Johnson, Jeff Markwith, Maya Shimoguchi & Randall D. Wilkins, set dressings by Frank Hendrick, Kevin C. Lang, Daniel Newton & Meagan Skerchock is great. The costume design by Marlene Stewart is great. The special effects coordinated by Eggert Ketilsson, supervised by Michael Meinardus is great. The visual effects coordinated by Danielle Bemis, Patrick Halm, Chelsea Kammeyer, Zhunan Li, Sebastian Meszmann, Elizabeth Montes, Hayley Perkins, Sharina Radia, Cara Samuels, Deborah R. Scott, Julia Smola, Adrian Steel, Shanshan Xie & Siyun Yi, supervised by Eric Barba & Bjorn Mayer is great. The stunts coordinated by Robert Alonzo & Joey Box is great.

This is a well-done, well-crafted sci-fi / action / adventure film that is entertaining and well-made. This is a film that also has an interesting and intriguingly-done concept that is / or has been solidly interpreted on film. Tom Cruise gives a solidly great performance as Jack Harper. Joseph Kosinski has crafted a film that is completely different and original from his previous film, "Tron: Legacy", the sequel to "Tron". This is one of the best sci-fi films of the year and probably, one of the best films of the spring season, as well.

There exists an ache deep within each of us, longing to know who we are, where we came from, and why we were created. Deep down in the core of our being, we know there is something more. Like Jack Harper, we do not want to simply live a purposeless life as the security repair man; a sterile life of a thousand repetitions.

In this sense, Jack typifies all of humanity in this movie. In him, we find the war waging within each of us. Do we allow ourselves to forget who we are? Do we give in to sin, and allow it to dull our intellect, even our memory? How many of us have lost our joy, our vigor for life. How far we have fallen indeed, and how sad and cynical we have become. Earth really *is* devastated. Yet there is still hope for humanity, in compassion, in love. In this way, Jack serves as a figure of all humanity, who's self-revelation marks a new beginning for mankind.

Yes, I know, I read into movies too much.

This movie is as off beat as Tom Cruise himself.  Sure this was a action filled science fiction movie that moved quickly  with lots of "Booms" and "Bangs", lots of technology talk that nobody really understood in the movie theater. Let's not even mention Tom Cruise's lousy acting. This movie moved fastly and was terribly confusing until halfway through the movie. It was one of the worst movie's I have ever seen. For a movie that had so many special effects it was boring and all over the place.

Over the course of the last few years, the science fiction genre of film has either provided major hits or complete misses.  Depending on who's acting and who's directing, movie-goes appear to be fairly picky about which sci-fi films they're willing to spend their money on.  In 2012, Prometheus took us back to the Aliens universe with critical and commercial success, while at the same time, Battleship and John Carter sank - ultimately drowning in a sea of misery.  Speaking of sci-fi success, Tom Cruise has been a part of a handful of lucrative sci-fi endeavors, including Minority Report, Vanilla Sky, and War of the Worlds.  Now, Tom Cruise is back once again with another pre-summer box office smash, Oblivion.

Directed by Joseph Kosinski (Tron: Lecacy), Oblivion stars Tom Cruise as Jack Harper, one of the few remaining survivors of the planet earth - half of which has been destroyed and deemed uninhabitable after a nuclear war with an alien species, known as Scavs (Scavengers).  Harper, along with his partner and love interest, Victoria (Andrea Riseborough), are in charge of an operation to salvage and extract the last of earth's natural resources, prior to leaving earth and rejoining their fellow humans on a massive space station, called Titan.  However, everything is not as it seems when Jack saves a woman, Julia (Olga Kurylenko) from the wreckage of a crash-landing - the same woman whom he has been having recurring memories and dreams.  And, after making contact with the Scavs, Jack must uncover the secrets behind the organization for which he has been working and the reasoning behind his absent memory (which was mandatorily removed) .  Morgan Freeman and Melissa Leo also star in supporting roles.

First and foremost, do not leave the theater when you see this film - and you absolutely should see this film.  Oblivion is one of the films that will require your attention at all times, because it's extremely easy to miss a giant piece of the puzzle during a bathroom break or popcorn run.  The film's plot is relatively easy to decipher by the conclusion of the film, however, there's more going on in this film that you can possibly interpret in one sitting.  The introduction of the film crams a whole lot of information into your head to set up the present conundrum being tackled by Cruise's character, Jack Harper.  Clearly, he's involved in a snatch-n-grab job, hastily attempting to remove earth's resources, while attempting to avoid any difficulties or interaction with the supposed villains, the Scavs.  However, it's impossible to get specific about the majority of the film's plot points without spoiling the film.

Oblivion's cast is one of the most impressive features in this film and remains tremendously authentic from beginning to end in this enigmatic drama.  Tom Cruise hasn't been this enjoyable in quite a long time and really finds his groove with his character.  Reminiscent of the character from War of the Worlds, Jack Harper is mostly in the dark about the majority of the occurrences in this film and is often in over his head - yet somehow always manages to come out of each dire situation unscathed.  On the other hand, his partner (Victoria) constantly finds new ways to be jealous in a world where she has absolutely no competition.  At times, she can become an annoyance, but that's mostly due in large part to lack of her unwillingness to think outside the box (which is reserved solely for Tom Cruise's character).  Finally, let's face the fact here - everything is better with Morgan Freeman.

By far and away, the most enjoyable moments of the film revolve around the CGI action sequences - which include some very intriguing and well-designed drones.  These drones are the main agitators in a rather Empire Strikes Back-like flight batter which is also a nice flashback to Tom Cruise sitting in a cockpit in Top Gun.  It's unclear whether or not the filmmakers meant to create a throwback sci-fi Top Gun-style chase scene, but regardless, this specific flight chase will have you wishing for a Top Gun sequel (which was sadly cancelled after the death of its original director, Tony Scott).

Overall, there's absolutely nothing in Oblivion that hasn't been done in some other sci-fi before it.  Sure, it would be easy to say this is just another post-apocalyptic film with alien invaders, ultimately forcing humanity to unite for a greater good to defeat them.  Yet, this film is much more complex than your average space-invaders film.  It provides a busier (occasionally confusing) than usual plot (in Prometheus fashion), so if you look away, you'll most likely miss something important.  But, if you play close enough attention to the plot points, you'll be able to tie everything together in a nice, pretty bow when the credits role - hopefully coming to the conclusion that Oblivion is a perfectly fun and enjoyable sci-fi film.

Overall Film Grade:  A-
FNDNreview.com

In his follow-up effort to 2010's Tron: Legacy, Joseph Kosinski brings us Oblivion, a visually striking and futuristic sci-fi epic that boasts a strong performance from Tom Cruise and an intriguing, albeit recycled, story.

In 2017, Earth is transformed and deemed inhospitable due to an invasion by an alien race nicknamed the Scavs. Sixty years after this event, the human race has abandoned the planet for the Saturn moon of Titan. Only two humans remain, Jack (played by Tom Cruise), a security repairman who is tasked with fixing security drones, and Victoria (played by Andrea Riseborough), Jack's communications officer and partner. Due to join their fellow compatriots on the enormous space station known as the TET in two weeks, a vessel crash-lands on Earth and causes Jack to question everything he knows about the people he trusts, his mission, and ultimately himself.

The biggest achievement of the film belongs to Kasinski, who's vision and direction make this film an absolute wonder to behold. Much like Tron: Legacy, Oblivion contains breathtaking landscapes and dazzling futuristic designs. The look and feel of decimated Earth is truly spectacular and oddly realistic. It's an amazing achievement in visual effects, and it's for this reason alone that seeing the film is worth it.

Another impressive factor of the movie is the cast, which is quite small. Jack and Victoria get the bulk of the screen time as the first half of the film is devoted almost entirely to them. Luckily, Cruise and Riseborough have a great chemistry and pull of the "last two people on Earth" thing quite nicely. Cruise continues to prove age has not diminished his action-star status and he's particularly good here. The film is more character-driven than the previews would have you believe so having a versatile and well-known actor in the lead spot is a definite plus. A lot of credit also has to be given to Riseborough who is absolutely brilliant in her role as the content worker bee who doesn't want to see the facts laid out in front of her.

The one caveat most people seem to have with the movie is that it heavily borrows ideas from many other sci-fi flicks, including Moon, the Matrix, Total Recall, and Eagle Eye to name a few. I find this kind of silly because most sci-fi films borrow from each other in some way or another and while most of Oblivion's ideas may not be entirely original, the execution and visuals more than make up for this. It's an inventive and strikingly beautiful sci-fi epic that holds it's own when it comes to character development and overall story. If you're a fan of sci-fi (or any of the above-mentioned films) definitely check this out.

This is my first new science fiction movie I've seen in quite a while, and was well-worth viewing. The entire cast did a good job with acting performance, and visual and sound effects are excellent. In comparison to other science fiction movies such as Independence Day, the action in this one is much slower, but entertains from start to finish. The story is intriguing, and I was content with the part that Tom Cruise played. I've seen him in other science fiction movies, and his acting fits well within this thrilling story. There is enough events going on throughout the film to hold your attention, along with suspense for the final conclusion. Overall, enjoyable and highly entertaining. Recommended to all those who enjoy thrilling, science fiction movies!

What do you get when combine the themes from Kubrick, Spielberg, Scott and The Wachowskis sci-fi masterpieces along with some elements of Mass Effect and the mind of director Joseph Kosinski? You get Oblivion an unoriginal, but yet visually stunning and a fun and entertaining sci-fi film.

The film was adapted from Kosinski's own graphic novel with the same name. It is 2077 the moon is destroyed and the Earth has been devastated by the event along with the war with the Scavs that took place sixty years ago. Humans won the war, but had to leave after it became an irradiated waste land. The remnants of the human race migrated to Titan a moon orbiting Saturn. Back on Earth a two person mop up crew of Jack Harper (Tom Cruise) and Victoria Olsen (Andrea Riseborough) repair the drones that protect the machines that harvest Earths resources to take back to Titan. The couple lives a quiet life with just two weeks left to go on their mission. Victoria is content and can't wait to head to Titan. Jack on the other hand yearns for more in life. He has a longing to remain on Earth, and has even found a private Oasis where he has built a home along with that and his dreams of a seeing a beautiful woman on the Empire State Building compels him to explore Earth and collect artifacts and take risks, which get him into trouble and realizations about Earth, the Scavs and himself.

Does the story take elements from other films like other critics have voice in their reviews? Yes without question Oblivion does. There are elements from films like Planet of the Apes, 2001 and The Matrix to name a few, but that shouldn't take away from someone's enjoyment of Oblivion. It is virtually impossible to come up with an originally idea with everything have been done before. It is up to the writers and directors to bring their own take on the themes and story along with trying to create a unique vision that will captivate, and bring wonder to the audience. Kosinski wasn't able to create something truly unique, but he was able to bring his vision to life. The story is pretty well done, and yes there are two predictable moments some audience members will be able to predict like who is the bad guy in the film. I was able to discern that pretty quickly, but there are a couple of twists I didn't see coming and certainly don't think most views will be able to predict. The romance and chemistry between Jack, Victoria and Julia Rusakova (Olga Kurylenko) is genuine and believable, and plays an important role in the film.

Tom Cruise has garnered some criticism in his last handful of films for basically playing the same character and rightfully so. There isn't a whole lot of difference between characters Roy Miller, Ethan Hunt, Jack Reacher or even Stacee Jaxx. Tom Cruise has proven he's a very capable actor he just needs good director to push him out of his comfort zone like Michael Mann did in Collateral or Steven Spielberg did in Minority Report or Oliver Stone did in Born on the Fourth of July, and here in Oblivion he's given one of his best performances in years. Is it on par with some of his best? Absolutely not, but he does give a good performance showing what he is capable of and giving a wider range of performance besides his lad back happy go lucky smiley face performances he's given us in his last couple of roles. The two leading ladies also give good performances in their roles of Jack's loves. Andrea Riseborough is believable as Victoria and you can clearly see her love for Jack. All she wants to do his go to Titan with Jack, so when shows emotions like betrayal and regret it's all the more believable and meaningful. The beautiful Olga Kurylenko also does a good job as the mysterious Julia who Jack rescues. Just like Riseborough she does a nice job of conveying emotion. Morgan Freeman as Malcolm Beech is given a lot of screen time in the trailers, but in Oblivion he is just a supporting character. Beech isn't the best character for the likes of Freeman, but the actor does a decent job with the Beech and the character does play a pivotal role in the film.

The action is sparse in Oblivion, but when it happens it is extremely well done whether it is an airborne chase through a storm and canon or a battle in a bunker the action is riveting, and the special effects are really well done. The detailed ruined Earth that was created is beautiful and richly detailed. That combined with the cinematography done by Claudio Miranda makes Oblivion one of the most gorgeous sci-fi films. Miranda is the same person who helped bring the world of Life of Pi to life. Just like in Tron Legacy where Kosinski brought Daft Punk in to give soul to the film he does the same here in Oblivion by bringing in M83 to do much of the films score with Joseph Trapanese. Together the two give sadness and soul when it is needed along with adrenalin boost where it is most needed. The two match the score to the scenes perfectly.

I have never read Oblivion the comic, but from what I've read Kosinski had been trying to get this film done for years, until he basically gave up and made his story into a comic. Finally being allowed to bring his vision of a futuristic world to life director Joseph Kosinski does a pretty good job with his follow up to Tron Legacy. This is his baby he birthed and brought to life basically on his own. He had a clear vision of what he wanted to create and it generally worked. Kosinski is a talented director and I can't wait to see what is next for him which is hopefully the sequel to Tron Legacy.

I understand the critics, but even with Oblivion being inspired by and taking elements from other sci-fi classics Oblivion along with writer and director Kosinski still managed to bring to life a stunning sci-fi vision with a pretty good story, good acting, great visuals and action, a great score and pretty good directing. I originally had high expectations for Oblivion, and while not living up to them Oblivion is still a good sci-fi film that I recommend to sci-fi fans and people who just want to have a good time.

In "Oblivion," Tom Cruise plays a repair tech named Jack Harper who travels an abandoned Earth in the year 2077 fixing robot drones. A war broke out years ago with the nomadic Scavs, the only threat still roaming the planet. While the Scavs lost the war, they destroyed the moon and made Earth uninhabitable. Now Jack and his assigned team mate Victoria (Andrea Riseborough) are the only two people left while the rest of the population relaxes comfortably on Titan located on Saturn's moon. Despite a mandatory memory wipe for everyone on the planet, Jack still dreams of a woman that isn't Victoria. He begins to question his mission when a spaceship known as The Odyssey crash lands near Jack while he's out on a run and the woman from his dreams literally falls into his lap.

The only other film Joseph Kosinski has directed is "TRON: Legacy," so does that mean the soundtrack has to sound exactly the same? To be clear, the soundtrack isn't bad but you kind of write it off because it sounds so similar to Daft Punk's soundtrack of Kosinski's previous film. The one main difference is that there is a ton of synthesizer near the end of "Oblivion," so much that you can actually picture an astronaut on the moon playing a keyboard guitar during the slower moments of the film.

That sense of familiarity seriously plagues "Oblivion" because it will remind you of at least half a dozen different movies during its just over two hour duration. Tom Cruise seems to intentionally make nods to "Top Gun" while flying his futuristic dragonfly-shaped helicopter thing. He even pulls out a pair of aviator sunglasses and places them on a shelf in this delicate "remember this?" kind of manner. "Oblivion" seems to make the mistake of having an expected sci-fi plot point in its loins without much of anything else to back it up. To get there, it piggybacks on the likes of "I Am Legend," "The Matrix," "Independence Day," and "Moon." The issue is it feels like it doesn't try hard enough to leave a big enough impact to actually be remembered by the end of the year let alone six months from now. "Oblivion" is like a clone of a clone of a good sci-fi film.

Tom Cruise spends a lot of time flying around, sticking his fingers deep into the innards of broken robots, and turning them on. All you'd need is for him to whisper dirty things to them while his fist is still inside them and you'd have some futuristic porno on your hands. "Oblivion" is absolutely breathtaking to watch. Earth may be deserted, but it's still beautiful in this empty kind of way. The lush landscapes are incredible. Pretty much anything involving the drones is a lot of fun. In a way, "Oblivion" is a lot like "Mission: Impossible - Ghost Protocol" since the futuristic technology is really creative and just a blast for the audience in general. The drones make so many beeps and boops that you know somewhere R2D2 is getting a stiffy. If you have an inner sci-fi nerd, the intense visuals and electronic sounds of the film may give you the same reaction. There's a drone chase sequence near the end of the film that is pretty outstanding.

But somehow everything else going on is really dull. Tom Cruise is torn between two beautiful women? How tragic! Morgan Freeman shows up long enough to do his best Morpheus impression and smoke a cigar in the dark. You can see where the film is going to go, but poor Jack takes an extra 45 minutes to get there because he's got to figure out who this other woman is (which you can figure out the second or third time he dreams about her). Most importantly you won't care where the film is going to go. You can see the big finale coming once Jack returns to that cabin for the second time. The story being told is just so dry and stale. Imagine clipping coupons with a lightsaber or using warp speed on the Star Trek Enterprise to get to the laundromat to fold clothes and stretch either of those tasks out for two hours and you have "Oblivion."

"Oblivion" is visual science fiction ecstasy yet is so structurally boring that you'll be edging towards the door two thirds of the way through the film. It attempts to mold this futuristic adventure out of borrowed concepts and mimicked ideas from similar genre films, but it does not compute. It is not an effective team.

"Based on a graphic novel" means another comic book-based story. I'm sure you expect subtle nuances and sophisticated philosophizing, but.... In this dystopian setting (of course) we visit the ruins of well-known American landmarks as our hero is sent to finish the eradication of a few survivors who cling to the remnants of Earth after an interplanetary war. The moon has been destroyed and we see the effects of the resulting earthquakes, while aliens "farm" the remaining water. Computer Generated Imaging is used very effectively, although some of this was shot in Iceland, California, New York and Louisiana. The Empire State Building is a critical element.

It is impossible to talk about the plot without revealing important points, so rather than do an entire review that is a spoiler, I'll stay pretty general.

We see:
  * Tom Cruise ("Jack Reacher" and "Rock of Ages") is more appealing than usual; this time he plays the stalwart soldier on assignment to "mop up" any survivors.
  * Morgan Freeman ("Olympus Has Fallen" and "Dolphin Tale"") is one of those survivors trying to avoid being "mopped up."
  * Nikolaj Coster-Waldau ("Headhunters" and "Game of Thrones") is currently my favorite Danish actor. His character is another one of those survivors attempting to remain alive on Earth.
  * Andrea Riseborough ("Disconnect" and "W.E.") is our hero's partner, sharing that mop-up assignment.
  * Olga Kurylenko ("Quantum of Solace" and "Paris je t'aime") is the survivor of a crash, rescued by our hero.
  * Melissa Leo ("The Fighter" and "Flight") is the Commander's voice and face on the communications screen, issuing orders to our mop-up crew.

Pay close attention to the plot, as it is satisfactorily complex. I liked one "sink hole" that turned out to be the ruins of the New York City Library. Please note that this cast has been assembled in keeping with Tom Cruise's international stardom. His movies are successful throughout the world and they keep his fans in mind when his movies are cast. This is a very good one for him.

This is rated PG-13, so expect lots and lots of gunfire, no sweaty bodies, a couple of swear words and nudity only alluded to, but the crux of the story is a "mind-wipe" that erases memory, so pay close attention. Amazon will notify me when the DVD is available.

Here is Tom Cruise's latest movie in a single sentence: It's "WALL-E" with a heavy dose of "Moon" and "Total Recall," and a touch of "The Matrix" and/or "Terminator."

If you've seen these movies -- and most other sci-fi from the last thirty years -- "Oblivion" will seem oddly familiar. Admittedly, being derivative isn't necessarily a death blow to a movie. But being dull and spiritless is -- and while director Joseph Kosinski crafts a truly beautiful, brilliant post-apocalyptic world to play in, he never crafts a story or characters half as interesting.

Sixty years ago, an alien invasion was repelled... but not before they destroyed the moon... which seems to have just made Earth temporarily inhospitable rather than permanently lifeless. The human race has evacuated to Titan, and the only ones left are a "clean-up crew" who live in an iHouse high in the clouds, and use drones to exterminate the alien "scavs."

WALL-E... sorry, I mean Jack Harper (Tom Cruise) is regularly sent out to repair drones, but he's more interested in the ruined remnants of human civilization. But one day he finds cryo-pods from a crashed ship, and barely manages to save one of the survivors, Julia (Olga Kurylenko) -- whom he recognizes from half-recalled memories.

While trying to help her out, Jack stumbles across a small band of surviving humans, led by Beech (Morgan Freeman) -- and he finds that they are planning to blow up the TET, a human space station. When Jack refuses, Beech sends him off on a quest to discover the truth rather than... well, just telling him what's going on.

Joseph Kosinski has only done two movies, but he's already developing a distinct style: bland story and gorgeous visuals. "Oblivion" is a truly beautiful movie, with sweeping views of an Earth that has been completely devastated, but is slowly being reclaimed by nature. The only oasis is the cold, sterile iHouse, set in a perpetually rosy cloudbank atop a slender pillar. It leaves you thinking that Kosinski has dreamed up designs for the entire planet, and just wants to tour his postapocalyptic world.

Unfortunately, the plot is a Frankenstein's monster of other sci-fi movies. Almost everything in this movie has been done better elsewhere, either directly ripping it off ("Moon") or in cliche form (oh dearie me, what IS the connection between Julia and Jack?). And there's no passion or energy behind anything that happens -- it all feels bland and generic.

And Kosinski is just awful at expositing anything that ISN'T ripped off from those other movies. Major plot twists flew directly over my head because of how blandly they were revealed -- for example, the big reveal involving the TET.

Sadly the characters are just as bland and generic as the story. Tom Cruise is basically playing the Generic Tom Cruise Action Hero here -- a good, morally-upright guy who has some murky stuff in his past. Even the character's NAME sounds like a GTCAH name. Cruise gives a decent performance, but he's definitely not stepping outside his action-hero box -- and the character is so blandly nondescript he probably couldn't even if he wanted to.

None of these characters have pasts, quirks, other relationships, or anything to really flesh them out -- they're as blandly uninteresting as the plot.. Kurylenko is pretty awful, Freeman is phoning it in, and Melissa Leo and Nikolaj Coster-Waldau aren't given enough to do. The only really good performance is Andrea Riseborough as Harper's lover/partner, who is made pretty miserable by his attraction to Julia. But alas, she also is not given much to do, and is gotten rid of when she becomes inconvenient.

"Oblivion" is a visually entrancing movie, but the Frankenstein plot left me feeling empty and bored. Directed by someone other than Kosinski, it might have been an astounding film... but instead we just get a bland, forgettable one.

Oblivion is a movie that projects great expectations, delivers even greater CGI (its smoothless and does not detract from the movie as some CGI in other movies has a propensity to do); however the ending causes this film to fall quite flat on its face. If there is one major fault with Oblivion its that there is a sense that it draws far too much on past Sci-fi movies (I found myself comparing particular scenes with previous movies - some now quite dated - and such reminicising drew me away from the premise of the movie itself) with the ending (no-spoiler here) pretty well much a re-make of a well known, but now quite aged, sci-fi movie (and thus a real dissapointment).

Oblivion is an enticing journey into a post (dare I say) apocalyptic earth where mankind has truimphed over an alien invasion and Jack Harper (Tom Cruise) is left behind with his 'partner' as a cleanup/srvice 'mechanic' of giant sea converters. I am not a particular fan of Tom Cruise however here he harks back to his better days of acting and carries this film with a degree of aplom. Like other reviews here, I agree that there is far too little exposure of humans and how they have coped with life in this new earth and much more could have been done to explore this aspect, furthermore I was very dissapointed at the 'Alien' content and the ending of the film reinforced this, as in how they, the aliens, were portrayed.

Oblivion started well, built at an excellent rate, maintained my interest - and then suddenly fell completely on its face at the end :( (hence only 3 stars and 2.5 of them are for the CGI and the futuristic technology). Oblivion is still a good movie to see, however in my 'humble' opinion its not a GREAT movie - watch it, enjoy it, just don't have too many great expectations (sic).

The scene set as we are lead into an impressive post-apocalyptic Earth, the textures and colours are vivid and almost photo shopped; the remnants of Man's world are literally fused into the landscape, or disintegrating amphitheatre of an American football stadium, we are shown the pitiful spire of the Empire State Building. This is all the result of a Pyrrhic victory against extra-terrestrial interlopers called `Scavengers', in principle the human race has essentially given up on Earth.

On this `barren' world there appears to be a couple who are doing their stint as caretakers to help maintain harvesters that are harvesting the last of Earth's riches water for fuel - and mopping up `Scavengers'. What is left of Humanity lives on a large orbiting satellite while the rest have moved to Titan. Jack, who does the maintenance has a partner called Victoria, who is a communications specialist and lover, they live in `Sky deck', high up off the ground, a rather amazing uncluttered command centre. They even have a glass bottom swimming pool for tempting night dips.

If we look past the visuals of landscaping a post-apocalyptic world, the interesting futuristic Sky deck residence, `bubble-copters' and amazing colour palette of photography. The story while interesting, the components that make up the whole have been borrowed from a number of other films and the ending while drawing together the story threads, was disappointing, because it based on movie's perception of alien intelligence or lack of it. That said, while many have panned this film, for me faults and all it was good.
Very good movie the suspense and futuristic approach was wonderful.
another good cruise movie with a fresh script
It's a movie. You either like it, or you don't.
These two actors together in a movie...great
Another excellent lesser known movie by Cruise.  Excellent movie and story
great in 4K!

If you enjoy movies with an awesome score, the threat, that in my opinion, the discovery of intelligent alien life pose to humans and mystery, then this movie is for you. Whether or not you like Tom Cruise, the acting, story and visual effects of this movie are outstanding. Couldn't even tell you how many times I have watched it...but its a lot.
Good movie!
This is a very relaxing beautiful powerful semi action movie, we will watch again and again
Good Sci Fi, or sci-fi if you prefer. The ending is interesting but a bit unsatisfying - at least to me. It has good action and good plot twists. Cruise and Freeman are excellent.
